text: Healthcare Professional: and the report right now so I’m just gonna Doctor: Oh like for July? Healthcare Professional: Yes. So, if you can sign and date, I’m sorry to interrupt you, Doctor: No, no no Healthcare Professional: but I figured if I can get it while… Doctor: J____ is like Speedy Gonzales. She’s like let’s roll, let’s roll. Healthcare Professional: It’s really so I don’t forget it later. Doctor: Okay, we’re having a good discussion. They were afraid I was gonna give them a quiz at the end of it but I think we’re good. Healthcare Professional: Alright, I promise not to, no, I probably shouldn’t promise I won’t interrupt again. Doctor: Of course you won’t. Family Member: So, if it’s bone only after the scans, Doctor: Yeah Family Member: it’s radium for sure?

Patient: It’s not quite that. It’s not so bad. Doctor: It’s much less so. Family Member: And there’s no affiliation obviously in Toledo that… Doctor: No. Not – well especially for these studies. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: We are under such strict regulations that we can’t even do it in our own satellite in F____. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Leave alone you know in any other place. Family Member: Sure. Doctor: Whatever we can do close to home we can, we do, but most of the stuff is not allowed. You know the FDA just regulates that pretty tightly. Family Member 2: Okay so I guess we’ll just stick with what we’re doing. Doctor: So I think uh, you know think about it. For now we’ve given you the pills but if you decide to come off based if today’s PSA is going higher regardless of the scans, that’s perfectly okay. Nobody is going to be mad at you. You’re allowed to make that decision. And uh…

Family Member: It’s between Johannesburg and on the Cape Peninsula area. Because that’s what they were telling us. Ya’ll need to put your feet in the Indian. Doctor: Oh. The Indian Ocean? Patient: Oh, yeah. Doctor: Oh, yeah, that’s right, the Indian Ocean. Family Member: Um hum. Yeah. Doctor: The Indian Ocean comes over to that. That’s wild. Family Member: Right. (Laughter) Patient: Oh, yeah. That was a deep, deep, deep, deep experience. Doctor: Well, I’m glad it all went well for you. Family Member: Yeah. It was nice. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: All right. We’ll get you moving.

Patient: I ain’t got no problem with flying. Doctor: No. Go do it. Patient: I want that jet. Doctor: I know. Go get it. Patient: I want that jet. I get the jet I’m good. Doctor: You’ll have a great time. Patient: Yeah. I’m gonna have a great time on my bike. Doctor: Okay. Just be careful. People worry. That’s all. Patient: I know, I know. I know how to you know make her shut it down. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Call me if you run into trouble. If there’s issues with your insurance we will let you know. Patient: Well doc we ain’t claiming that. Remember you said that last time and we made it.

Family Member: All beans. Good. Lentils. Doctor: Good. Family Member: Great cabbage. Doctor: Sure Family Member: Okay, okay. Pork and bread. Wheat bread, multi-grain bread? Doctor: Yeah, the more fiber the bread has the less processed flours it has. Family Member: Multi-grain, right, okay multi-grain. Okay, so that’s it. Now I know this is early and he’s feeling fine, but somebody brought it up and I want to ask you. When he starts radiation, chemotherapy is it possible to get the medical marijuana or how is that to happen? Patient: I never used my form, so we Family Member: And so we need to know in what form you know he should take Doctor: I hope he doesn’t need marijuana have an Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It’s only people who you know just have nausea that just can’t be controlled by medicines -

Patient: Can I go to England and get it? Doctor: Or one of those countries. I think Germany or England, yes, one of the European countries. Patient: I could go over there and do it. How long do they treat you, though, for that? Doctor: It’s about four doses, a total of four doses every six weeks or something. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So it’s not, uh, it’s not a one-time deal. Family Member: Wow. Patient: Yeah, I didn’t imagine, no idea. Doctor: Yeah. No. I agree. Yeah. So I think you should consider going on the study because that is our only chance, at least in the U.S., of getting on the medication. If you don’t, we are no better off than what we started with. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But now is a good time to consider the study because your cancer is not going crazy. Okay? Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? It’s only the PSA is inching up, but nothing else is getting worse.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Which is why I think the last conversation was on the vaccine therapy, Provenge. So I know we gave, we gave you all that information. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: I’m not sure he gave it to you? Family Member: No. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: No. He did not. Hum. Doctor: Okay. So did you explain anything to her? Patient: No. She tell me- Family Member: No. But, yes, this is why, right. Yes. This is why I’m here. Doctor: Ah. Okay. Family Member: Because I can’t get a good understanding. Doctor: Okay. Okay. We know the baseline stuff –

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And so half the people get it, half the people don’t- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: but you still have to come in and get an infusion three times a week. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And so that one is logistically pretty tough. But that is something that you know if we’re going chemotherapy, I can make sure we get you the permission slip or the consent form to let you know what that would look like. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may, I don’t think we have an opening at Hospital B but that’s one of the sites that we collaborate with, and I think they had interest in opening it, and so we can check in to see whether they have that open. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But that would be clearly if we say I’m doing chemotherapy, do I want to do something more on top of it, so that would be one option. Experimentally we have two treatments, uh one based on the fact that your ARV7 is positive. We have an experimental study where we give everyone immune therapy, a doublet. That is a combination of two drugs that are approved in melanoma, soon to be approved in kidney cancer that can turn on your immune system to attack your cancer. It doesn’t work all that well so far in prostate cancer, maybe fifteen percent of people may get a benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Doctor: Didn’t mean to interrupt you. Doctor: The light’s going to stay on? Family Member: She’s upstairs. Doctor: New patient? Family Member: Yep. Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member: Study patient. Well, not study. Off study. Doctor: But, oh my. Oh my. Family Member: Hi, Dr. H___. Doctor: Hi. Lovely to see your father. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s amazing. Just waiting on the final stuff from administration. Everything else is okeydokey. So he’ll take his time filling out this lovely paperwork while you do damage control and try to fix our inpatient unit, please. Doctor: Shoot. Patient: I’ve got several questions for ya now. If I get the drug, what are the most common side effects?

Patient: So, the first thing is to, uh, see if I can come up (healthy) Doctor: Yeah. Just to see, yeah, how much it’s gonna cost ya. (Pause) Family Member: Okay. Patient: I think last time I was on the Xtandi, they wanted to know if I have any income to speak of or – Doctor: Yeah. They’ll do the wallet check and everything. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If they think you make enough money that you should be able to pay for it, then they’re not gonna give you one of these, uh, uh, grants. Patient: Yeah. (Pause) Doctor: Yeah. Okay. Family Member: Alright. Patient: With the Xtandi, the PSA still has to go up. Doctor: I’ll write that out for you what we’re lookin’ at. Okay? Patient: The ARV seven has to stay positive and, uh, (stuff)

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Um to arrange a consultation, or a timely consultation with Dr. T in his clinic, which is in the building. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: And, on that particular day you would have read out any particular information about the trial and issue questions for him and his team. Um, and if those questions aren’t answered to your satisfaction go ahead and do that. Then after that you’ve basically completed the screening for randomization. Okay. So although the study is a randomized study, it’s not a blinded study. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But in the case of radiotherapy versus therapy, Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - would be which we thought wasn’t really ethnical Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So I think a lot questions may arise after you look at that. Patient: Okay Doctor: Yeah um I don’t think I’ve given you that consent form. first time you’re seeing it.

Patient: Yeah, I’ll just stick with the prednisone. Doctor: Okay. And you can definitely try cutting back on the dose okay because as you saw in the scans, remember last time I had given you a slight inkling that it was heading starting to grow back? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And when we did the recent scans are showing a continued slight increase. So it’s a small increase, the bone scan is still completely okay and so you do not have the spread to the bone that we can see. Patient: Yeah, right, right. Doctor: Uh because of that I think we should stop this treatment. Okay because you’ve sort of gotten the benefit you’re going to get out of it and it may be time to move on to other treatment. Now in terms of other treatments what to go to next? And uh there is a medication that is something called Niraparib okay. And it’s sort of this family of medications called barhabiters. And the way they work is if your cancer expresses certain specific mutations, they it’s likely to be effective. So if you treat everybody with your kind of prostate cancer on this medication, the chances of it working were wherever fifty to twenty percent, so pretty low. When we looked at just the people with those mutations that were expressed in the cancer, then the response went up to seventy eighty percent. So what we’re doing… Family Member: For prostate? Doctor: So what we’re doing – yes, yeah, within prostate cancer. So what we’re doing now is what we’re proposing is that we screen your uh blood, it’s a blood test, that to look for any of those eight genes or mutations that if your cancer has those then I would recommend going on this particular study which gives you these medications which are pills that you would take and we’d monitor you to see if it’s likely to be helpful. Family Member: Is it a type of chemo? Doctor: It is not. It is something called parp… so more like what we call targeted therapy. Okay but it’s different from the immune therapy that you were having. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And I think it has a pretty good shot at working like I said if you had one of those mutations.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Anyway. Patient: Yeah. Uh, the last time that that you saw a spot or spots on my bone, you used radiation to go with it. Doctor: Right. Patient: So what, what’s the difference this time? Doctor: Well, I think we saw, you know, a few, you know, small number of spots. We thought like we could radiate them. Maybe those are the only spots. Patient: Right. Doctor: It looks like there’s more now. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I, I don’t think we could do that radiation. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, just because of the number of them. Patient: Right.

Patient: That’s- They were really quick. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. VIP apparently you are. Patient: Well, probably. Doctor: Well we said we just really need to know. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know so we’re we’re doing the whole we gotta come up with the next study uhh situa - and the good part is there’s more trials that opened up. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: which why I told J___ let’s give it another whirl before you know you get too… Patient: Yeah absolutely. Doctor: …pooped out from the Taxotere. So I got M_____ on it. I’m just trying to look at your ankles over there. Just swelling more or what’s? Patient: No. Doctor: Oh, it’s just your socks. Okay. Patient: Just socks. She was checking I think for swelling.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If you decided to participate in a different clinical trial, then, of course, you could receive that therapy here as long as K___ approved of you to enroll in that trial, which they probably will, because their general policy is if you’re participating in a trial at an institution that’s not available through K___, then they support that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you could definitely still be our patient, and we would love it if you were. Uh, we’ve gotten to know you for the past several months, and I think your experience with us has also been relatively good. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so, you know, that could be a win-win, but we have to make sure that it’s something that makes sense for you. We’re not going to put you on a trial just for the sake of keeping you at H___. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it just might be that we have something that really does look interesting or promising that we can offer you. I don’t want to go into those details today because I don’t know when that time will come or if it will come. But if that time comes, when we’re deciding between a standard therapy, like the two that I mentioned, or a different experimental therapy, I can give you the consent form, and you can think about it, and if you decide to participate that would be through us. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Because I know the discussion we had initially, uh, was the chemo. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: That was one of the options. And I used the word, chemo bad. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s bad in terms, you know, the side effects are worse than everything you’ve had so far.

Patient: …to S___, it’s a done deal. Doctor: Okay - No. N - honestly you gotta get off Casodex for six weeks anyways… Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: …so the timing is perfect. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Why I wanted you in here is one, we have a plan in place… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …so that when you go off on vacation you know what’s gonna happen when you come back. Patient: And I don’t make any airline arrangements from hereon. Doctor: Okay. Alright without checkin’. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Number two, that you know what our treatment plan is. So we can either preferred would be to biopsy before you go so while you’re on vacation we’re working on all of the stuff. And then when you get back we have a plan of either these pills, standard chemo, or chemo on a study.

Patient: Now see, I have, I have to, I have to always sit, I have to always sit down. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You know, because I be fatigued. Doctor: I see. Not a problem. Patient: You know what I’m saying? And, that, that’s the only problem (XXX) Doctor: I’ll give you a script take it over to Vincent’s or whatever and see what they say. Patient: I can’t talk. Like somebody’s stoppin’ and be talkin’ to me. But, let’s go walk up so ‘cuz I can’t stand up that long. Doctor: I see. Patient: And, also, I’ll be out of breath and then my legs Doctor: Yeah, Okay. Patient: get weak. I can, um, I’m all for the standing and talk, bro, that we are gonna talk, let’s sit down. Doctor: So, what do you want to do? Do you want to take a break from the chemotherapy?

Patient: Well. We would start first with the Xtandi. I have to – the disease has to progress some more – Doctor: Uh, by PSA only. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: I don’t think you’re gonna need new scans, but that maybe sort of something down the road, but I think you, you really just have to have a rising PSA on the enzalutamide, and then we have to repeat that ARV seven. It has to be positive on enzalutamide, and then you can go onto the study. (Pause) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So, we can follow up that you can afford it. If you want it, then you have to decide, “Okay, I’m gonna take it.” With the idea that you’re going towards this, and maybe about a thirteen percent chance that the PSA will drop just because we added back the Xtandi. Okay? Family Member: Is that Xtandi a, a injection or a pill or – Doctor: It’s a pill. He takes four pills a day. Family Member: Oh, alright. I get it. Doctor: Gives you fatigue, tiredness. Patient: I had two extra bottles I gave back to Family Member: And then, uh, and then he’s going to take it for awhile. And he’ll come down here and get -- in a month or how--how soon?

Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: You want us to print it? Patient: Seven to twenty nine. Doctor: Yeah, it is, it is a mess. Patient: I haven't read it before. Doctor: I mean, most of it is, um, I say usual, you might get tired, because tired is always tops of everything. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: We always got to watch your blood counts, because we always got to watch your blood counts. And that means white cells, red cells, platelets, and then of course, liver and kidney numbers. But that's blood tests. So you don't necessarily feel bad from that. We do know that some patients, their platelets go down a little bit. And that in some other patients, you might get a little bit of stomach upset. So not like full blown oh my gosh, you can't eat anything. And if that is the case, then we would have to, you know, modify the medication dose. But you can get a slight, you know, nausea or upset stomach. So we'd have to figure out how that plays with you. Other than that, that’s about it, so it's basically another hormone pill. So Xtandi, tackles one pathway of the receptor. This pill is another pathway. They are somewhat related, but this is not a chemo, it's actually another hormone. Yeah. So we're just trying to make sure you're super castrated, and then some, and then some. Patient: There’s that euphemism for the Prius. Patient: So, how does it affect my heart? Doctor: So obviously, we have to make sure that we take care of it, it shouldn't affect there's no direct effect, you know, it's not like, here's the chemo and Oh, boy. The Xtandi is, you know, always has a potential for heart issues, because we can't say that it doesn't, because anything that touches that testosterone pathway puts you in more of a menopause and accelerates heart disease. But that's true with your, you know, Lupron, that's true for all the other pills you've been on. Unfortunately, that's the main sort of active drug with all of this with prostate cancer. So that's the tough part. This one shouldn't have a cardiac thing. But again, this is a study. So if you do have a worsening cardiac thing that's reportable, because we would want to make sure that no other person has that. Patient: So they don't know that? Doctor: Oh, no, this is why it's a study. I mean, this is- you’re guinea pig, once again, you know, like you tell us what's going on. But it isn't like this is a chemo or something that we're really worried that this might worsen heart disease. But it's always this- every time you fool around with the hormone receptors, you know, it can worsen heart disease in general. So I don't know about this particular combo, but that's why it's on a study and not me just go in here, take this.

Patient: Yes! I’ll take one. Doctor: You’ve got cancer, and I’m gonna treat ya. I’d like ya not to get the flu in the midst of therapy. Patient: Okay, then. Doctor: Because, then, it’s one thing I can cross off the list. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm. We could do it today, or we could do it in a couple weeks when you’re gonna switch the Patient: Whichever’s easiest to - Family Member: Why don’t we get it out of the way? Patient: Thanks, dear. Family Member: Well. Family Member: What are these? Patient: One less thing to worry about. (pause)

Family Member: Like by the tenth. Doctor: And, then, we’re going to skip Dr. S_’s appointment on April sixteenth, and then we’ll just follow with me subsequently. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And, um, um, Patient: By then, I will have had my – Doctor: I think you can get your hormone shot. Patient: My hormone shot. Doctor: I don’t know if you – if you get a hormone shot in January and it’s six months, you won’t need another one until July. So, that April version will just be a PSA check and see how we’re doing Patient: Right. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And maybe some more discussion. Family Member: Because that will be at least his third hormone shot.

Family Member: Yeah you were. We had an appointment with this guy Come in at eleven thirty. Right. Doctor: It’s all your fault his sugar is low, not back and forth. (Laughs) Patient: No. He said no (Laughter) Doctor: You feeling better? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Oh, they’re taping us now? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Oh, I didn’t know that. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. We’re getting his whole lunch live right now in color Doctor: Well I’m glad you’re feeling a little better. Just you know take your time. We’re okay. We’ll see what that PSA shows. I’m glad we straightened out the whole pill action and everything else. Patient: Yeah. That’s all been handled.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Do you want to do it in two months or three months? Do you have any preference? Patient: Well when am I going to see you again? Doctor: January would be reasonable. How about three months from now? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Do it about a week or two before? If I see you in mid-January? Patient: Yeah. We’re going to be cruising in January. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m sorry. January’s fine. Yeah, that’s fine. Doctor: Okay. Where are you going? Patient: We’re going to ____. We don’t know where. We’re going to so many places. The ship is supposed to stop at Puerto Rico and St. Maarten. So I know those two are . We do a lot of traveling. We just want to get away for a few weeks and we stay in Florida for three weeks and come back. Doctor: Okay, so - Thank you. You like it?

Family Member: Monday, the eleventh. HCP Thank you. Doctor: Okay, you did start physical therapy? Patient: Yes. Doctor: How is that going? Is it inducing more pain? Patient: That’s what I’m thinking it might be from right, right. Doctor: No, sometimes - Family Member: Sometimes, yeah. Doctor: No, my worry is that as we start chemo for the first few weeks of chemo until both of us figure out how you’re going to tolerate, how you’re going to do, maybe back off a little bit and take a break. Family Member: Back off on the - Doctor: And anyway, with the holidays maybe - Family Member: They did give him a set of exercises he can do – Doctor: Okay. Family Member: - at home.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Sound good? Patient: Thank you again. Doctor: Tell them before the end of July because I’m taking off June and July I’m having hip surgery. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So I’ll be seeing you though towards the end of July. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Did you want to see him before we go? Healthcare Professional: Yes I do.

Patient: So you would just give up on the Xtandi and just go with the PARP inhibitor? Doctor: And you know if we were going to do the Xtandi base treatment still then we would have to – I would say we need to combine it with something else and that something else could be the BET1 inhibitor. Patient: Is there a third option you said? Doctor: Well the third option is going to chemotherapy. That is definitely an option. I’m not favoring that right off the bat just now. Okay. Patient: We would do that as a last resort? Doctor: Well yeah. I mean not quite last resort. I’m not sure I want to wait (nervous laughter) Patient: What would you recommend? Doctor: Okay so my recommendation is mainly based on trying our best not to take away options from you, okay. And the way I see it if we go to Lynparza right now, this Xtandi plus BET1 inhibitor goes away as an option because you have to be on the Xtandi currently before when they can consider you for the study. So I’m leaning towards if you qualify for the study, if everything goes right then you should go with the Xtandi plus BET inhibitor the study based option first and if that doesn’t work or if it doesn’t if you’re not eligible for whatever reason, then we go to the Lynparza. I mean that is available to us as a fall back at any point. Family Member: Okay. Patient: So you’d say try the uh uh BET thing and uh if that doesn’t work go to the Lynparza which is the PARP inhibitor and continue with the Xtandi? Family Member: With, with the BET. Doctor: The Lynparza we’ll see, most likely I will stop the Xtandi at that point.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We also sort of know what side effects you’re going to experience to sort of see whether you can tolerate this. We have to adjust the doses about that. So that’s an approved drug that’s known to extend survival if people get the drugs, tolerate the drugs, respond to the drugs. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know those people can do well compared to those who don’t respond or don’t get the drug. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So chemo would be something that you know it could be given here, it could be given there, but it’s standard treatment. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have a clinical trial where we’re giving the chemotherapy and everybody gets an infusion two to three times a week. So- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: for someone coming from F___ may it may be too much to come in here that often, but we’re giving Vitamin C to half the people and half the people don’t because some data says that Vitamin C may reduce the side effects of the chemotherapy and also help the benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But we don’t know that. It could be just folly; it could be the truth-

Patient: No. My mom she’s… Doctor: Okay, somebody’s there right? Patient: Yes she – I just got to call – she out shopping right now. Doctor: Okay, no because I was gonna give you some Benadryl here also for your congestion. Sometimes um the… Patient: What’s it - For the sinus? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Patient: Yeah… Doctor: And it can help with any reactions that uh from the chemo too. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So okay. (whispering inaudibly to herself) Patient: No. Doctor: I’ll send it right here? Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: It’s the placebo thing? Doctor: Right. So, it’s placebo in the sense that the new drug is not guaranteed but it’s not placebo in the sense everybody gets chemo. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So, if there’s, you know, you’re guy one and you’re guy two you both get chemo no matter what. You might get drug and you might not. Patient: I got you, okay. Doctor: One of them you know. The other one you don’t. So, some it’s like oh, I’m just gonna get stuff infused in but we all kind of go gee, I wonder and it becomes a topic every time. The nurses try to guess. Everybody tries to guess. No one knows the answer except the people who actually hold the key. And then the other one is you know whether you get it or not because they just tell you okay, you’re just getting the chemo. But, the difference is you know everybody gets the chemo. That’s your standard drug. Nobody gets gipped out of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, a good question. It’s something that I have to always make sure people understand. At this stage in the game you should never be on a placebo only trial. Like it can never be either drug X or you’re crap out of luck. No, that’s never gonna happen. Okay? Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: And if anybody ever offers you that, that’s bad news. That’s just ethically wrong. So, we have a lot of watchdogs, safeguards, everybody’s looking to make sure that we don’t do something like that. Patient: Okay, Alright. Doctor: Yeah, keep going.

Patient: I want to get – I not only want to get that but I would like to get one that does further and maybe practices in W____ … Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: …and operates out of the uh works out of the uh W____ location. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Makes it easier for us. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know your numbers always suggest that you’re dry. You know like you’re just a tad dehydrated. It always runs a little high. The other number we check is the B.U.N. or the bun. Patient: Right. Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: When you put those two together like a ratio, you’re a little dry so you need fluids. Patient: I, unfortunately, the last two days that’s been a little bit difficult because I was sitting in meetings. Doctor: Ahh. Okay. Patient: And driving so uh.

Patient: Potassium. Doctor: That's right. That's for the secondary causes of hypertension. Okay. Okay, so that is, so that's that approach. The third approach is clinical trials. And clinical trials in general are where we're testing some intervention to see if it is helpful or not. The two that we have for people who have biochemical recurrence, there's one that's a natural products. And there's one that is a medicine called a PARP inhibitor. Patient: Mm. Doctor: The mainstay of treatment of prostate cancer today is hormone therapy, neither of those two therapies are hormone therapy. Okay, so the clinical trials that we have would be doing, they would be giving you some intervention, but it would not be a hormone therapy intervention. So sometimes people like that because they don't want to get started on hormone therapy. Because if your disease progresses, you got to get started on hormone therapy- Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: -and sometimes people, you know, don't want to be in a clinical trial. And so these are, the three general options. Family Member: Out of the three which one would you recommend. Doctor: Well, let me tell you a little bit more about what what the clinical trials entail, because then I'll tell you what I think, based on our conversation last time to what we should look into first. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So the two clinical trials one is called the MAP study. And I might have briefly mentioned this last time, this is a study of muscadine grapeseed extract. Family Member: Yes you did. Doctor: Yeah. So this is a study- is a randomized study for people with a particular genotype. So what that means is what what we know is that when some people take antioxidants like you know, these a lot like pomegranate or the muscadine grapeseed extract- Family Member: Mhm.

Family Member: And he’s not walking this time. He has an unsteady gait. He’s stumbling. Doctor: No? Really? Patient: No I ain’t walking the same. Family Member: And I told him he’s a fall risk so I’d like him to take his cane with him. He says well it’s in my truck, but you can fall going from the house to your truck. Doctor: I agree. Better to keep it. Family Member: Period. Doctor: It’s still better than having to use a walker otherwise. So that’s… Family Member: I’m not walking outside with that cane. That’s what you told me last week. And I said alright just go ahead and fall because I’m not coming out to get you. I don’t want to see you hurt that’s why I think preventive measures Doctor: A fracture now would really set us back. So- Family Member: Yes because we have brittle bones. Doctor: And I might put in for a bone strengthening medication just so you know it starts, uh it’s an injection. So if he can get it authorized and all that we might as well start it about every few months we’ll have to do it, so not that often. Family Member: I’m not opposed to that. Anything that will help J___ -

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, cool. Alright so next time I see you will be on the twenty eighth. His PSA wasn’t bad was it? Healthcare Professional: Down, down from so… Doctor: Just slightly down. Healthcare Professional: So slightly down. Doctor: Okay, it’s heading in the right direction. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: It went a tiny bit down so. Patient: That’s good to hear. Doctor: Um hm. Absolutely. Patient: I was wondering, they said theys gon’ have cameras on. Doctor: Today? Healthcare Professional: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, that’s our plan. So, going forward, you’re going to have to see me much more frequently than before. Patient: That’s fine. I like you. I would not mind seeing you more frequently. Doctor: Thank goodness. Doctor: hhh Now, that is something. Even though, I yell at you sometimes. Patient: Right. Noooo, I’ve got, Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’ve got a lot of respect for you. Doctor: Thank you. Sit up for a minute. Let me, uh, put down. (Paper rattling) Patient: Mmm.hmmm.

Patient: I need two weeks off. Doctor: Yeah. No, no, no, we’ll figure it out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s just keep things moving and we’ll figure it out. Patient: So J___ told me that his promise to you is he said he’ll get me squared away medically and then - Doctor: Yes, and then it’s time for us to take over! (chuckles) Patient: Yeah. ___ called me last night. He said we’re taking a break in oncology and we’re going to do some medicine. And I said okay. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That really made me feel good, for you, too, and for me. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Because I was like “You’ve got to do that or I get derailed from what I have to do.” Patient: Right. Doctor: So he’s on it.

Doctor: I had some Spanish-Portuguese, maybe Doctor: One of my grand, great-grandmothers had a little thing on the side. I don’t know. Doctor: Yeah, the joke is uh – Patient: He used to say that all the time, yeah. Doctor: Mommy’s baby, daddy’s maybe. Is that what I’ve heard? (Laughs) Family Member: It’s twenty-three and me --- Doctor: One of them tells you like how much Neanderthal you have. Ancestry didn’t tell you that. Family Member: It didn’t tell you --- Doctor: No, I wanted to know how much Neanderthal was in me. (Laughs) Doctor: Right, right. Patient: But that’s, uh, not so much the case anymore. That --- Doctor: Or how much – I’ve been watching these alien shows. I wanna learn how much alien Patient: Oh good, good.

Patient: Okay, Alright. Family Member: Just for the first few days? Doctor: Yeah, they’ll give you like a set time. Oh, yeah, yeah, yeah, and same thing, you know, when you go to the bathroom. It’s the same thing because he doesn’t want to nail you just because you’re sitting next to him it shouldn’t be but, you know, for the younger people or people who are more immunocompromised who are older they get at risk for stuff and we say why bother. Family Member: They won’t put a port in him will they? Doctor: No, we shouldn’t have to. We shouldn’t have to. Family Member: Even though when they get him they go to the Docetaxal? Doctor: Now, Oh, well, from a chemo standpoint we might have to negotiate that. For sure if you get on the high-dose vitamin C one that is more labor intensive because the chemo is once every three months, not three months, once every three weeks. He got hopeful there for a minute. No, sorry, once every three weeks but the vitamin C is twice a week because it’s at such a high dose. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Well, think about normal stuff you would pop every day you’d almost have to take it multiple times a day to get that dose. This would be the super high one so you’re here like twice a week for like weeks and months. I mean we hope it’s that long because that means it’s working, but yeah, that’s a bit of a slightly draining on that one Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but I have a lot of people who just want their hands on high-dose vitamin C because this is you know, formulated differently than just sort of generic stuff. This is really done with the right, you know, it’s made by a company that’s sort of a spinoff of Hopkins so it’s a very well-regulated product. Um, but, can I tell you that if you’re on placebo you still have to be here? Yeah, because I don’t know who’s getting what. So, the three of us would be fast friends for weeks. Every day it’d be like hello, hello. Just take your name and tape it on an infusion area and you’ll see M____ and S____ all the time. So, that’s one but we’ll work on that. Patient: Okay.

Patient: No. I still wake up a couple of times a night you know and go but uh other than that I’m pretty active, play golf a couple of times a week. You know? Nothing slows me down. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I don’t have any bone pain. Don’t have any muscle pain per se. Uh. Doctor: So today we’re just going to go over stuff. And I, I mean it looks like unfortunately there’s been some changes that probably we’ll, we will have to call off the study. Patient: Oh is that right? Doctor: Yeah. Uh so the PSA to start with went up just a little, uh, so. Patient: It’s up around forty something isn’t it? Family Member: Six. Doctor: So it was forty-six, forty-three, forty-nine. So that’s almost the same number to me, maybe a little bit elevated from the last time. And then uh the bone scan we did looks pretty much the same. There’s really nothing new. Uh they’re seeing this bone spot they saw before, looks about the same. Uh they thought they saw a spot on the left side of your sternum. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Well that’s been there for- Doctor: Yeah. So that, that really, they don’t really see anything new. So the only thing that’s changed is you have a couple of lymph nodes in the abdomen, pelvis that are, got a little bit bigger. Patient: Oh they have gotten? Doctor: Yeah. So uh so they looked along the aorta which is the main focus for down the body.

Family Member: And when he does that does he see you at that time? Doctor: Yeah me and if people live around her they see me. If you know have a relationship with Dr. F__ and that’s closer. Family Member: I would like to keep you both though because I think you know it would be more convenient to be close to home and I know they have state-of-the-art equipment there because I’ve already talked to the manager of the cancer center and um and then to still be coming here. To me it is. If that’s okay with you. Doctor: Do you want me to send him a text right now? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah? (pause) Family Member: That’s fine. Patient: Yeah that’s fine. Family Member: That’s fine because I could set up an appointment with him to just kind of go over things and I don’t know when they’ll want him to start. Doctor: When your control is better. Family Member: Do we decide that or do we come see you again first? Doctor: You decide it with Dr. F___ but don’t rush into it. Patient: Right.

Family Member: Right, Okay. Doctor: -combination that you just outlined kind of again makes sense, but I view it as to me the main purpose of doing the radio therapy would not be necessarily that you will have some sort of combined benefit in conjunction with the hormone therapy. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It would be for the purpose of delaying the hormones that much longer. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: So I kind of view that as the primary motivation for doing that. But to me the primary motivation for radiation would be we’re doing something rather than just continue to observe you. Patient: Right. Doctor: But that’s something may not be so as aggressive or as detrimental on your quality of life as the hormone therapy, for example, which has all these systemic side effects. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So I wasn’t necessarily seeing it as hormones plus radiation at the same time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I was seeing it as doing the radiation therapy as a way to sort of avoid or push back the need for the hormones.

Patient: Oh yeah, yeah. Doctor: Maybe it will cool down a little bit. Patient: Yeah right, yeah. Doctor: But let’s not do it too fast because remember even before this when we tried to get you off of it… Patient: Yeah I had issues. Doctor: You had a major revolt. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So let’s take it really slow. Family Member: The only issue he had he was nervous at first it might be his kidneys he was having a pain on this side, but then it switches to the other side. So I think it’s his back. Patient: I think it’s my back. Family Member: Yea, because it went from… Doctor: Does it hurt now when I push? Patient: No, no, no.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And then something like the Zofran or Ondansetron that you have at home is what we use in the middle of the week if you had nausea after the chemo. Family Member: Mm. Tiredness was my biggest obstacle. Doctor: Tired is definitely. Family Member: Fatigue was unbelievable. So have you decided? Patient: Too early to decide. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: Yeah, so we need more information about the chest scan. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I want to give you some stuff that you can sort of read to educate yourself a bit more on options. And again you can lay it off to Dr. G as to his thoughts as to what the next steps would be in terms of scans or such. So other questions while I do a little bit more of this paperwork stuff? (keyboarding) Family Member: No, I don’t think so. Patient: I can’t think of anything. Did you go to M___?

Patient: Merci Beaucoup. Doctor: Hope for the best right? Patient: I’m still recovering from the call and everybody keeps pushing their hand out. Why don’t you do the fist bump? Doctor: Yeah the first bump. Yeah I guess I should get with the times. Patient: I guess the fist bump is less contagious isn’t it? Doctor: Okay now maybe. Yeah you’re right. Although my son has told me that is - Family Member: Out? Doctor: -would be very weird if I did it. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah there are some words that are off limits for me. Patient: It’s medical purposes. Doctor: Yeah exactly. No don’t try to be cool with your kid.

Patient: Give me the glasses. Doctor: It can also affect your skin. Some people, their skin gets very thin, and they bruise easily, particularly at the higher doses. So we, we could try the other one. I, I mean- Family Member: But you feel that would be less tiresome-? Doctor: Well, I just tell you my global experience with both drugs. Doctor: Has been it seems like both of them has a side effect, fatigue. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But my experience with using both drugs now, it seems like it’s a little bit more with the Xtandi. Uh, and the other question is, you know, we do have a couple of trials of Xtandi, uh, that, uh, I don’t know if you’re interested in going on another trial at this point. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Right. Doctor: So, uh, so what I could do is talk to the pharmacist about the Xtandi and just figure out what it’s going to cost us, and look into the trials to see, uh, if we would- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I don’t know. Are you interested in doing another trial? Or are you sort of, you did a trial, and you’re ready to-? Patient: Well, no. I mean, anything that, that might help me to survive. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. I know. I know.

Patient: I can tell him thanks for buying her a new car. Doctor: He didn’t buy it. Healthcare Professional: She probably bought it (chuckles) Patient: Oh it’s you – it’s your it’s everybodies - it’s both your monies; it’s not just - Doctor: No, no, he is just, yeah. No, but he’s really trying to drive it as much as he can right now. Healthcare Professional: Yours? Doctor: The problem, well the worst thing is my son sent a picture to all of his friends and you know my sister; he sent it to his cousin, my sister’s kids and so they told my sister and I hadn’t had a chance to tell her that I bought this car. And she’s like, “Are you out of your mind? You bought N____ a Mercedes?” (Chuckles) Healthcare Professional: Oh they thought it was N___’s car. Doctor: He sort of - sent the text out as if it was his car with a picture of my car. HCP OH! Family Member: His car. Oh my! Doctor: But now he doesn’t have any car because he’s in college. He doesn’t have - HCP Oh okay! Family Member: The Mercedes Patient: He’s lucky he’s having college paid for.

Patient: And when the end of the day is all over, you nap. Doctor: Mm, hmm. But it sounds like you’re pretty good about sorta if I have to take a nap today, I will or if I - Patient: Oh yeah, if I know I gotta work late, I nap now and stay up late later, and sleep when I can ‘cuz I’m having some days with no troubles. It’s Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: Okay, so those orders are out. So, you’re going to the purple wall. Swipe your card. And they will sorta set up the follow-up visits, and then they can take you upstairs. You’ll go onto the second floor and swipe your card again, and that will tell them that you’re here for your flu shot. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Before you do all that, you’ve gotta finish up with T_. Family Member: Right. Patient: Alright, okay. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Anything else? Healthcare Professional: Have you sign the green, right there for me.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Still if you cough or pick up a heavy weight – Patient: Mm,hmm. Doctor: - still even a few years from now maybe a drop or two might come out. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Hmm, okay. (Pause) Doctor: It means that um there’s not enough prostate cancer cells to be detectable by the blood test. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There could either be zero or there could be some somewhere. It’s just not enough for it to be detectible. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So therefore getting a CAT scan, bone scan, it doesn’t, it’s kind of a waste of time because even if something’s there it’s not enough to actually be seen. Family Member: Be seen, okay. Doctor: On a scan.

Patient: And so the likelihood of what you’re seeing reoccurring is is is it high, minimum? Doctor: I would say, I would say based on so far minimum. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And if we go a year and find it’s still undetectable, uh then I think that uh that chances are very good that if it does reoccur that we can control it. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: I would say if it goes beyond a year I would say the risk is minimal and it continues to decrease. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And so we’ll see in three months and see what it is. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And um uh…

Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: So, this is a prescription for Norco so theres, you know, it’s five slash three-twenty-five Patient: Okay. Doctor: so I think we provided one hundred twenty Patient: Right. Doctor: so we don’t want you to run out. Obviously, if you take all one hundred twenty at one time you’re in trouble so don’t do that. Patient: I would say, yeah I’m not gonna do that. Doctor: You take one or two at a time. Family Member: Call Monday and say we need more. Patient: Yeah, right. Yeah, this stuff’s really good. Doctor: The next thing you know the DEA is going H____ I hear you’re off this. No, not me. And I think here we have to, let me see, how do we get this from you? So, this is just a lot of the, sort of like a list and a contract if you will. Sort of these are all the risks, this is why we’re doing it. So, every time we prescribe opiates we have to do that now. Patient: I have to sign this? Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: Yes I am, yes I am. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yes I am. I wouldn’t take the new ones that you give me and the old ones too. No- Doctor: Alright. Patient: -because I know the old ones they they they hadn’t been any good for me but made me miserable. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I lost five more pounds. I got to gain my weight back. Doctor: Well yeah you got to get your teeth back in. Patient: I’m going, I’m going, I’m making the appointment Thursday. I’m going and having them take these out of here. I don’t know, I might have to pay for some more because I don’t think my insurance will cover this, but I want – I’m gonna do it anyway. Doctor: See what they say. Meanwhile though I need you to be drinking those Ensure cans. Two to three a day. Patient: I got it your husband he wrote me a thing to go down there and get me two case. I’m gonna get a case of Ensure and Boost. Doctor: Good. Patient: But I’m gonna be eating and next time I come here…

Patient: Ahh. Doctor: But because the cancer is you, if you go too far, your immune system starts to see you as foreign, and we get colitis or pneumonitis, lung inflammation, appetite . So there’s, so it’s a, it’s a balance. It’s promising but the side effects, you know may be a little bit scary. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Uh that probably would also require you to have a certain monitor in your blood, and what that monitor is, uh, some men, particularly if they have been on a lot of hormone treatments, lowering treatments, the cancer evolves and adapts. It starts making this version of uh a receptor for the hormone. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, I, I, I use this value of kind of a baseball and glove where testosterone is the baseball and the receptor is the glove. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And to be together. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So everything we’ve done so far is to try to keep the ball away from the glove. (Beeping) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The cancer sometimes will evolve a form of the glove that doesn’t need a ball. It, it still works.

Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Uh don’t wait you know for having, having sex with somebody, Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: take it so that uh, it’s like medication you would take on a regular basis… Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: Take that so that it keeps the blood flow going. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: And with time, like more months, like up to September. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: In September if that that – if nothing happens, then we can go to another ah step Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: in treating the sexual function.

Patient: Right, right.. Doctor: Like every single time when you started the first day I met you we’re always behind the cancer. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Stuff happens and I’m reactive. Patient: Stop doctor, we’re not saying that word no more. Doctor: Sorry about that. We’re always behind the thing. Patient: The thing, yes. Doctor: However, what we need to do is get ahead of it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So we’ve got the Provenge in. I think there’s another set of pills, these are FDA approved. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It is not experimental. Patient: Right.

Patient: From when I talk to people, first dose of chemo, most of the guys that I talk to, not a huge impact effect with nausea or, or anything. Um, it was the second or third that they really started to feel um - Doctor: In my experience, the first cycle is the hardest in some ways, ‘cuz you just don’t know what to expect. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, when am I gonna feel tired? They told me I’m going to have aches. They told me this, and then if it happens or some of it happens. Uh, so we’re trying to give you. But usually, that first cycle sorta gives you your pattern. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I felt good, and then I felt tired, and then I was really wiped out, I had to sleep a lot that week and then I felt really good and they had to do it again. (laughter) Patient: Where would I find that information? Healthcare Professional: Like the timing? Of the course -- Patient: No, the, eh, um. The aches and pains, I got a bunch of them. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Patient: Just, more -- But like the ridges on the nailbeds. ‘Cuz if I, if I notice something that is abnormal and say, “MMmmm.” I’m gonna make a phone call. But that’s gonna just doesn’t make sense. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. In your consent, it has adverse things to expect, what are more common, what are less common. It’s in your consent. Patient: Okay.

Patient: So what’s goin’ on, so what’s goin’ on with my bones? Doctor: Nothin’. Patient: He just said that somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: No. I didn’t say anything. Patient: The other doctor that came in before him, before Dr. P_, said somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: Oh. Doctor: G_? Healthcare Professional 1: He had progression on his bone scan and CAT scan. That’s what he might have gone through. Doctor: Oh, could be. But his bones are not progressed. It’s just the, um, lymph nodes. (Pause) Patient: No. Doctor: I’m the one bringin’ it up because I see it on the scan. Oh!! We gotta do something. We gotta do something. But, from a functional day-to-day, it’s not really buggin’ you. If you were peeing poop, it would bug you. You would know it. It would frighten the heck out of everybody, but that’s not what’s happening. So, here’s a chance where we can proactively think about it and not wait until it’s an emergency. Patient: I’m not peeing poop.

Family Member: Yeah. Thank you Jesus. Doctor: Um hmm. Family Member: But um he was asking me did he ever have an MRI of the prostate lymph nodes. Doctor: Prostate – no, I don’t think so. Family Member: No. Doctor: He had a CAT scan. Family Member: Yeah. Now will that show if there was any problem or would it? Doctor: Well – Family Member: I know MRI show more. Doctor: Well they both can show that. I think it’s more of what are we looking for to do with that. Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: He’s sort of past that.

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …and it would show probably very small areas. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um and those are non-targetable. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that’s just the – the struggle is unless that thing whichever one decides to block anything off… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …we tend to treat it systemically. Patient: Okay. Doctor: …with pills or IV or whatnot which we’ll talk about. So I don’t want to cut you open, but I do want to re-biopsy you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and I talked to our radiologist. He’s gonna see at the time that you’re on the table of the CAT scan what is the best area to target because these things all move as well. Patient: Mhmm.

Family Member: His last PSA do you have the results of that? Because we didn’t get uh… Where did you have that done? Doctor: I only have CBC’s from outside, so I think - Patient: I had I had a PSA done. Doctor: - today’s PSA is going to be your one in a long time. Family Member: Okay well he had one… Doctor: Because when they did it in F____ all they did is only blood counts right? Patient: Uh, yeah. Yeah, B___ City. Family Member: Yeah – oh – I don’t know. Doctor: Are you saying he did a PSA in between in F____? Family Member: I thought so or in B____, yeah. Patient: I got to check. I’m not sure. I thought C___ had it. Doctor: Okay because the only results I have is all the blood counts. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: At what point would you do the scan? Is it when it goes above one? Doctor: When it goes above one. Patient: And that would be here at JH? Doctor: I would recommend that; it’s not absolutely necessary. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Typically you can do everything in one single day. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So you’d come in in the morning and you’d get your CT scan and you’d have your bone scan. And two or three hours after the two scans are done you would see me and by that time you would have the results. Have the images on my computer to look at them and discuss the results with you. The other possibility is to do the scans at a local radiology facility and then to get the images with the CDs and have the reports, get them sent to me and have one brought to you physically. But you know like I said if you agree with me, is to do it here. Patient: Yes. Doctor: If it’s not too much of a hardship. Patient: Very good. If when and needed. Doctor: Yes. And again that might not be for another six to twelve months. It could be sooner, a bit later depending on how or if your PSA increases. Patient: Oh.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But uh we’ll see how it goes. Family Member: Alright. I know in the beginning it will be more - Doctor: Next week though I was going to say just so we have enough time to get the results back, we should plan for like Thursday or Friday so we give it enough time because you know my worry is if I have you come in next Tuesday I may not have the results back from today’s blood work. Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: So back here next Thursday or Friday? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah I was thinking Friday might be a little bit safer just to be on the safe side. Next Friday. Family Member: Okay. So just the one day? Patient: A week from Friday. Doctor: Yeah, yeah just for the one time. And that time you’re not getting any treatment it will be just to make decisions. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The other way we could do it is we could do two weeks from today, but uh then the end of treatment stuff that S needs to do for this particular study since we’re stopping this study, that needs to happen within ten days from now.

Patient: I was gonna say something oh that uh you know I had – I got some sleeping pills from a friend of mine. He’s a former nurse- Doctor: Okay. Patient: -okay so he done retired and stuff, but he gave me two sleeping pills that I took – and please believe me, I took with my OxyContin pill. I was like here – y’all just don’t know. I was feeling so good because the OxyContin was making me feel good, then I took a sleeping pill, I went right on to sleep. I slept the whole night. I didn’t wake up until the next morning. When I got out of bed this morning, I felt so good. Doctor: So did you ask him the name? Patient: Um ro-ro-roe or ro something like that, but it was – it – I mean I feel so good. I slept through the whole night. Doctor: Restoril, Restoril is a pill is a sleeping pill. Patient: Okay because they gave me that Ambien. I took one of them and a half of them, I slept two hours and I was back up again. Doctor: Okay so want to switch the Ambien to the Restoril? Patient: Yeah I mean if it’s gonna make me sleep through the whole night to the next morning. I’d love that because- Doctor: Okay. Patient: -I when I get my sleep I’m more active. See that’s why I lost a lot of weight because of that. Doctor: Alright so I can make one change at a time. Which one do you want to go? Do you want to go with the Oxycodone change, the Percocet, or what do you want to do?

Patient: Yeah we’ll get - What’s the, what’s the group that he’s in? Doctor: I think it’s really like B______ Nephrology. There’s only one big group there. Family Member: Okay. Patient: M___ Kidney Consultants. Oh, okay. Doctor: Yeah and they may be called that. Yep. Patient: And yeah, yeah that must be because that’s their office in R___ and T___... Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: Yeah so if you call and say hey who’s out there with uh you know at the R___ Branch, um… Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: There’s - there’s many, there’s many, but they literally are all good. Patient: I want to get – I not only want to get that but I would like to get one that does further and maybe practices in W____ …

Family Member: You don't know yet if you want to do the trial. Patient: If I do the trial. I take what they give me. Family Member: Oh, that's right. Doctor: Yeah there's no choice there. Family Member: So if he wants to go somewhere, what’s the longest period of time he can be gone? Doctor: Oh. Well, probably three or four weeks Family Member: You can handle that. Doctor: Yeah, there is like a you know, plus minus, so if it’s like a special thing you know, might be five or six weeks so we can work with you guys. Because people have lives and they take vacation, they have other things they gotta do. Family Member: Right Doctor: That isn’t just cancer. Family Member: Actually I thought it was going to be worse, but you’re saying it’s every three weeks or so. I’m pretty surprised. I’m surprised. Doctor: Yeah, for standard dosing, just no trial, just once for an hour every three weeks is the infusion. Of course you know, I K_____ world that's a half a day, but still, it's not you know, every day you have to be here or anything like that.

Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Because they’re not all the same. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so you always fuss about that. Because there’s other people giving high-dose vitamin C Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but you can’t guarantee the product. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Here I’m happy to say the product is definitely of high grade. Uh, but you’ve got to give it two days out of every week. Okay? So logistically that means as long as they are given twenty-four hours apart, you can just come up once, and the study pays for you to stay overnight at a hotel. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? But that’s weekly. Patient: Okay, well I - Doctor: So like you’ll come up. You’ll get the one day where you get the chemo and the vitamin C. The next day 24 hours later you get vitamin C and you can go home.

Patient: Yeah. It really is sort of out of pocket. Family Member: But he could do it right away? Doctor: He could potentially. I, I, at least I could contact my contact and find out. I also know the group in Heidelberg. We could find out. Uh the groups here, uh I don’t know the Cornell group and the group at UCLA. I don’t know. Those are trials. So they’re going to have eligibility. Patient: Do you think I’d be eligible for them? Doctor: I don’t know. I, I can look into it. Patient: Yeah. I - Doctor: Well, I mean, I don’t know. I can find out from the group at Cornell which sounds like at least would be- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Within striking distance for you from, from the east coast. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: How quickly? If you’re eligible, how quickly you could uh- Patient: Sure. Sure.

Family Member 2: So you don’t have any more questions K___? Family Member: I don’t think so. (Laughs) Doctor: Yeah I know, she said that. Family Member 2: We’re glad that she was able to come. Doctor: Yeah, no that’s wonderful. Yeah it’s important to… What do you think or are you ready to bail from this treatment? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You are. Okay. No that’s critical information that I need to know (laughs) Family Member 2: He doesn’t like the trips. Doctor: I know, know. Patient: Yeah, that’s the thing. Family Member 2: It’s, it’s, it’s, it’s you know, now it’s only like every three weeks so… Doctor: Yeah it’s not too bad.

Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: You know smaller volume, here, three to six ounces rather than eight/ten. Family Member: Okay, okay. Is it, did it matter if he’s gluten free not? Doctor: Yeah, there isn’t anything about gluten-free diets and prostate cancer. You know how he feels on having the gluten uh. It’s not an association with prostate cancer. Family Member: And cancer in general? Doctor: You can that way. Family Member: How about rice—brown rice, white rice? Doctor: Yeah, if he’s going to have rice we prefer the brown rice Family Member: Yeah, that’s what she thought. She was asking about beans. Doctor: Well. Family Member: Like navy beans. Doctor: All beans are good.

Patient: I just want to be around a little bit longer, that’s all. Doctor: Well, our hope is that as well. Huh, my sense is, you know, these next drugs we, huh, huh, can get you a little bit more mileage, and you still haven’t had chemotherapy, which could get you some mileage. Huh, there’s an IV radiation drug that can get you a mileage. Most of it’s kicking the can down the street. Huh, we’ve got clinical trials at different points of new drugs, different drugs, combinations of drugs, huh, that we could think about. Huh, yes, so there’s a lot of things out there. It’s a matter of how much you want to go through, the rest of your body, your heart, the other things can get through because the next two drugs, we pick one of them. Huh, one of them is abiraterone, which is probably the cheaper of the two. It’s just gone generic. That doesn’t mean it’s cheap. Huh, but it’s about eleven, twelve thousand dollars a month. Huh, we check with your insurance carrier to see how much they cover. Huh, are you, huh, Medicare, Medicaid, huh, regular insurance, or-? Patient: Right now. Family Member: The next couple of days he’s regular insurance, but he’s going to get Medicare the first of March. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And that will help out. Patient: March first I start Medicare plus a supplement. Doctor: Yeah. Maybe with part D? Family Member: Yes. Patient: D and F, I think. Doctor: That would be great. So again, we may want to ask our pharmacy to look at the medicine next week once you’re on Medicare. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, because again, they will pay eighty percent.

Family Member: Yes. It’s a small dose. Doctor: It’s a small, it’s relatively, it’s enough that, you know, it’s going to probably, well, depends. Some people don’t, some people actually even a little dose, they feel, some people feel like really good on it. They feel like they have more energy. Patient: Right. Doctor: Some people just feel weird. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it’s enough, a small enough dose, that you probably won’t notice it, but. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Right. Doctor: But, and it’s also a drug that if you take it long-term, you can get side effects from it, in terms of immune system. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: People tend to, you know, it tends to pop your appetite up, so you feel like you want to eat more. Patient: Give me the glasses.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I appreciate both of you coming in. I really do. Patient: Well, thank you. I appreciate the time that you spend. Doctor: Oh, of course. I just wanted to wrap everything, yeah, because, you know, this always happens in medicine, right, we have one path and we’re like we’re going this way, it’s like no, everybody to the left, everybody to the left. We’re just regrouping. We’re just regrouping. Thank you both. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: I’ll get all the paperwork, get your scans set up and I’ll see you guys next week. Patient: Alright. That sounds good. Saturday we’re still… Doctor: Oh, that’s great. Come hungry for breakfast because the buffet is like. Patient: Alright. Great. Doctor: Yeah, it’s the best part, I mean other than the speaker. Patient: Right. Doctor: See you guys.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if we have to, we really have to, we will, but I’m going to try and work around these dates. Okay? Patient: Why don’t you let me sign it now so I don’t have to come back? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. I’m going to have S___ come in and so she can bring the consent in. Okay? Patient: How’s your husband? Doctor: He’s doing well. Thanks for asking. (Laughter)

Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: Yes, yes. Doctor: Um and it just depends on where you want to see this person. I’m – Do you see the B______ docs? Patient: Yes. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Yep. Are a R____ or T____? Patient: R____. Family Member: R____. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Preferably B______ in uh W____ even. Doctor: So there’s a large nephrology practice at B______. And they’re scattered everywhere. Patient: Right.

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: But here once we send it they bill your insurance. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Then we get the report back and we’re up to about eight hundred genes that they look at. And some of that actually is important for us because it sometimes can direct what we do whether it’s a trial for now or later and also gets us a sense of what that cancer looks like blueprinted. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which you know it’s a different blueprint than what you were born with. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So along the way there with you say ‘well gosh what else do you need to take the samples for’ when you know us we do lots of research here. Patient: Sure. Doctor: So parts of that, I think we talked about this the last time, when I take extra samples I will then do actual research stuff on that… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …which includes you know growing it outside of you, putting it in mice, working with all – all sorts of other things. For me to do that I have to have a consent form that we’re gonna go over. Patient: Mhmm.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: If there’s a lot there, so things look really dark, it looks like it’s taken up like crazy, then you’re a good candidate for that treatment. If it’s so-so, I don’t know what their line is, but they kind of look at it, and if it doesn’t look like the cancer is really taken off, I don’t think you’re a candidate. I would say that most people are in the first group that the cancer makes a lot of this uh so uh one of the things we’re doing here is uh looking at the scan part. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we’ve been looking at the imaging part to see how useful this is as an imaging agent but it’s also useful because if we do it here, and you’re very positive, it might suggest yes we should pursue this. Patient: Okay. Is it something than can tell you how extensive the cancer? Doctor: Yes. So the second part of that, it’s a good question. Just to, and because it’s very sensitive, it’s possible you do the scan, and they, say, oh, B__, your set of these, so many things you see here, there’s a lot more. Because they can see uh, what we’re limited by right now is as I told you these lymph nodes are enlarged. That’s pretty much all the radiologist can say right now. So if you have a normal lymph node it could be totally full of cancer. They won’t call it. They only call the ones that are bigger than normal. Patient: I see. Doctor: That’s the criteria. Patient: I see. Doctor: So this PSMA scan picks up those normal things that are too small. So often patients will get upstaged in a way where you thought you had five things and told that you have ten. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you’ve got to be prepared for that kind of news that there’s more there.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Like next Tuesday or next Wednesday. But I think either way, because of this anemia that has come back, uh, the trial at the very least will require us to stop the medication until the hemoglobin increases. Patient: Hum. Family Member: So are there other things that he can do like, say, for instance, you know, maybe take an iron or, but are there food products that he can eat that might help with increasing, uh, his blood? Doctor: Well, there’s many, you know, causes for anemia. And the only one of them that is helped by iron is iron-deficiency anemia. Iron-deficiency anemia is typically, one, caused by bleeding from somewhere. Family Member: Hum. Doctor: So, uh, I really don’t think you have the iron-deficiency anemia, and so, uh, I don’t think that will help that much, unfortunately. You know? I wouldn’t discourage you from taking iron if you want to. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: Or if you want to eat iron-rich foods, uh, like- Family Member: But you’re thinking this is basically because of the medication? The study medication? Doctor: Yeah. I’m pretty sure. I’m pretty sure because, I mean, he actually had some degree of mild anemia before he went on the study. Part of that could have been from the cancer of the bone or marrow, specifically, but clearly when he went on the drug, it got worse, and it dropped back one to two points. So, uh, but you might need a transfusion, however. But that’s a possibility. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Doctor: So as of today, you know, stopping the . Okay? Uh, let’s plan to do, uh, forgot what the lab was. Is it K___?

Patient: And if I don’t hear nothing, then how long, should I call you? Doctor: Give me a week. Just you know, if you use MyChart, you can give us a call. I’ll just follow up with them. They’re usually pretty good about it. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. That’s it. Doctor: Other question you guys have? Patient: Do you want me to leave so you can talk? Family Member 1: No. But we knew this. We knew that the first line of drugs wasn’t going to last forever and we were going to have to go to a new line of drugs. And when this doesn’t work, we’ll go to the next line. We, you’ve been very honest about that since day one that that this is how it was going to go. Doctor: And you told me you’re holding your own so you’re hanging right in there. Family Member 1: Right. Doctor: You’re still better than when you started. Right? Patient: Yeah. Huh, you said it, well, it’s a concern from one to three hundred and fifty. But you said from the beginning you don’t want it to go over six hundred. Family Member 1: No one said that.

Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that’s a reasonable study for ya, but you know, again, you would Patient: Screw a weekend, yeah. About an hour and half of life. Doctor: Um. So, that, you know, again, the vitamin C has to be given here because we’re paying for it. Patient: Right. Doctor: The other study that right now, the-the call that I got interrupted was about your eligibility for a phase one study. Uh, that is a first in human of a brand new drug that we’re evaluating only in prostate cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, So, it is also an infusion, and I’ll have to pull it up. Uh, I don’t know how often you have to be there, but it – there is a slot available. It says that, uh, it has to be people with bone disease only. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um, they used to say that you had to have only Abiraterone or Enzalutamide. Uh, but now, they have broadened it, that if you have had Abiraterone AND Enzalutamide, you can participate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that one would be an option for you. Um. It’s uncharted territory. Patient: No chemo drug, though?

Family Member: a problem that we’re going out of town? Doctor: When are you going? Family Member: Saturday. Doctor: No. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: No. We won’t, I mean, with the holidays, you know, nothing happens. It’s almost like a, not a for sure. Next week it’s a shutdown, but a lot of places are still not functional- Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: -the first week of January.So, and, that’s, you know, reality is probably mid-January, I would imagine. Patient: Okay, well then… Doctor: Okay? Patient: We are leaving town on the… Family Member: The twelfth. Patient: The twelfth, and we’ll be gone for the twentieth. We’re going to Phoenix then.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I’ll tell him about you though. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But he’s coming May ninth. Patient: Alright. Don’t you leave me yet man. (Laughs) Doctor: I hope so too. He’s the man right? Patient: Yeah, yeah you’re the man but you have more grey. <____> refer me to you. Doctor: I hope that when I see you next time I will be able to give you news that yes he’s coming. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And so, so we do this blood test all the way up until September. Doctor: Oh we’re still gonna do the blood test. I still get blood tests.

Patient: So he, but actually, the oxycodone are the ones with the numbers there? One or two at the beginning. Because that’s the way he did it. And when I do it, I just put down when I’m taking it. I don’t that, take it that often. I know that, uh, uh, when I got the prescription, they told me to stay in front of the, the pain, so, or else you’re going to have to start from scratch again to get back where you were at. But I was a little leery of taking, uh, uh, uh, drugs that often. Doctor: So it looks like some days you’re taking it twice, like August eighteenth? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then some days, like August twentieth, you didn’t take it at all? Patient: No. Doctor: And twenty-first, you didn’t take it at all, and then the twenty-second, which is today, you took one in the morning? Patient: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today. Doctor: Do you think the experimental drug is working? The Patient: Oh, I, I know it’s working. I believe it is. Doctor: And what makes you think that it’s working? Patient: I believe it from the perspective of where I was having pain at and not, uh, from a perspective of, uh, uh, uh, uh, since we lowered the doses- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: That I’ve been feeling pretty good for the most part. Uh, just as long as I don’t overexert myself. And that’s one of the biggest things, that, you know, you’re feeling good. And you said, okay, I’m going to do a little extra today, and that may be a no-no. You know? So I, you know, even at my church, I got up and, uh, I think that was two Sundays ago or three Sundays ago, and, uh, I stayed up too long and I preached too hard. And I paid for it the next twenty-four hours of doing it. I should have just cut it short. So what I do now, is like last week, they had church conference meeting. And I came up on Saturday for church conference meeting to let them know I wasn’t coming up for Sunday services and had one of my associates to –

Patient: I mean I miss getting chiropractic treatments. I know I can’t do that anymore. Doctor: No. Doctor: Don’t even go there. Patient: Now, is your position the same on inversion now? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you want to do a nice gentle massage to get the muscles, no problem. I’m all for that. Patient: Okay. Yeah. Doctor: But, no (sound of crack) Patient: I don’t. Doctor: You don’t want to (sound of crack) Patient: I know, I know not all MDs Doctor: Yeah

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah, Yeah. Because we can have S____ call you or somebody in our social work team. Do you want to do that? So we get proactive on this? Patient: I’m not ready for that. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. Patient: Um, but I know that that help is there. Doctor: So yeah, of course. Patient: You know, I'm not retiring tomorrow. Doctor: No, we don't want to leave you hanging. Patient: I mean, I don't think I am. Doctor: Right. So you're not planning it? Patient: Yes. Right. Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Okay. So I think, you know, depending on so you'll finish reading the consent, if it's of interest call M___ back and say, okay, their next step would be to bring you in and actually formally review everything and get blood work on that day- Patient: Mhm.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, I’m planning on getting scans next week and seeing Patient: Okay. Doctor: You anyway. So, within a week or two, I’ll be able to tell you. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: What we are doing. Okay. The Zytiga, now this is a very specialized medication because it’s for cancer. Okay. So, we will need to send it to a mail order pharmacy. There are these specialty pharmacies Patient: Mmm, Okay. Doctor: That deal with this medication. So, Patient: Because I’ve got a mail order through my job, too. Doctor: Which one? Patient: My mail order is called E-h-i-m. They deal with mail order prescriptions. Doctor: Okay. This one, though, has to go to a specialty pharmacy.

Patient: You should have had uh, you should of had something here from where I had three broken ribs from a car wreck which I explained to the guy. You’re gonna see something there… Doctor: Yeah, yeah… Patient: …from a car wreck. Doctor: And it wasn’t even that that prominent. Patient: You’re gonna see stuff there. Doctor: You got that, I saw that, yep. So the good part is it’s, not the good part but, it’s primarily localized right here. So the question is what to do. Now one, I know you’ve asked about well why can’t we just go in and radiate or do some stuff there. Patient: It wasn’t quite that simplistic. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I understand the, you know I, I, I you know basically I said if I have a mass… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …that’s to me a target, if I have a target. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: and if I’m at the range with my Glock seventeen…

Patient: I, uh, I guess the one question that I had, um, reading the, the paperwork and then this conversation - You’re waiting until after the chemo and then four weeks after chemo before any spot radiation for any, any sites that have popped up. Why not treat the one spot now, that I’m, the, the rib? ‘Cuz you can’t operate there. And, I understand radiation pre-surgery on the prostate, probably not a really good thing to do and then have surgery. But, the rib - why not do the spot therapy? Doctor: Because the hormone’s gonna take care of that. The chemo is gonna take care of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The radiation is gravy. That’s the bow on top of the package. Patient: Gotcha, okay. So, it’s, it’s not a primary treatment then? Doctor: No. We’re going to everywhere the cancer is, whether we see it or we don’t see it. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, you know, then based on sort of what we do see, we’re gonna sort of pinpoint that. Patient: Okay. Tallyho. Doctor: And, so, other thoughts or questions? So, typically, what we would do is I’m gonna give you a prescription for a pill drug today. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, you take it, you take it for thirty days and then you stop.
