Uh, in two weeks you come in and you get your first hormone shot. Patient: Okay.

Patient: So when you say three so what we determined so far is that it – it’s in one lymph node, so. Doctor: It’s possible that as part of this trial if you decide to look into it more – PAT; Um, hum. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: PSMA stands for prostate-specific membrane antigen. It’s a protein that sits on the cell membrane, on the surface of the cancer cell – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - and if you can imagine if you have radioactive molecule that binds which to your protein that’s found on the cell surface of your cancer cell and that can be used to um uh produce a picture like a light bulb, bright area of light, that we um – that we can sometimes pick up cancer that cannot be seen on a conventional CT scan or conventional bald scan . So it’s possible with that kind of scan we might find more than one spot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We might find two, three spots. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Perhaps lymph nodes, which could be hidden or camouflaged with a conventional CT scan. But everything up to three we will be able to do stereotactic radiation for each of the three metastases. Because more than three then we feel it’s beyond the scope of this trial, it also becomes um less feasible and less practical to target five, six, seven spots. Patient: So at the beginning of the trial you’ll do that scan and that will determine whether I’ll stay in the trial if it’s three or less? Doctor: I believe that the PSMA Pet scan is optional. It’s something that they will discuss with you-

Patient: Oh good, good. Doctor: Alien DNA. Patient: My doctor watches the alien shows (laughs) Family Member: That’s everyone. Does that make you feel better. Patient: Okay great, man. I feel great now. I just, I just took the survey “Do I trust my doctor?” I gotta go back and change it. Doctor: Oh, my lord. Doctor: I find it interesting because they, not about the alien part, but they tell you a lot of cool stuff about weird places on earth that you didn’t know about. You’re like, oh, that’s kind of a cool place over there in, you know, Bulgaria or something. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, your next appointment is, uh, let’s see here. Patient: I have an appointment January twenty fifth for a hormone shot. Doctor: And to see me also? Patient: I don’t have anything, uh, with you yet. Family Member: Are you sure?

Patient: Right. Doctor: We just need a plan and know where we are. So, let’s just backtrack for a second. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If I say gosh, where is your cancer right now, I’m not sure if I can adequately answer that by scans because the last one you had at Oakwood, hold on. Patient: Right, same thing, yeah. Doctor: Same thing, was July and then we did a quick scan to make sure nothing was happening, you know, here after the biopsy but that was just sort of kind of like limited. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But, your earlier ones prior to July were sort of January/February time point. So, if I just take down the bone, you’ve had a variety of different reports, right so your January one was lots of different spots and then I think your July one we don’t have an official report but it didn’t seem to change much, you know, kind of different spots, but then on the CAT scan it only just showed one area because it was such a limited area that I would imagine that your bones still have multiple spots. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We know that your PSA hovers around the one twenty nine, one thirty mark. It’s kind of been staying there. It’s not five hundred but it’s not fifty, Patient: Right. Doctor: but it’s enough to say this might be the reason why, you know, you’re getting more tired and having some pain which may not be related to that. Now, your actual CAT scan reports are always a little inconsistent so that’s why I think it’s not confusing but challenging.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’d love for you to do it tomorrow, but the odds are we have to check your insurance and get the time slot and… Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: When are you supposed to take off again? Patient: Wednesday. As as I said to… Doctor: I know. You’ll… Patient: …W____ I’ll - I can be on a plane. I can drive it… Doctor: Okay. Okay. Patient: …in nine hours, in - I can drive it in thirteen hours it’s not a big deal. Doctor: Let’s work on that scheduling so I just want to recap so we’re straight… Patient: Yep. Doctor: …and then you tell me if this, actually you tell me, you tell me what I just said so that we’re straight. What’s our plan?

Patient: So what kind of pills can I take? Doctor: Huh, so the most common pill would be a drug called abiraterone or enzalutamide. Huh, if you’ll excuse me one second, I’ll ask one colleague a question. I’ll be right with you. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: The enzalutamide, what you were saying- Family Member: Let him, let him, let him ask a colleague a question. He’ll be right back. Patient: I mean I’m just- Doctor: Okay. You remember it? Patient: Well, huh, a doctor from Johns Hopkins two weeks ago worked on a girl, gave her this medicine, and everything disappeared. It’s in the paper. Doctor: But she didn’t have prostate cancer. Family Member: Right. (Laughs) Patient: All right. Cancer is cancer. Family Member: He’s seen something on TV. Patient: No. It was in the paper and TV.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, based on your interpretation, perhaps they’re a little bit better. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not putting words in your mouth. Uh, so before I came in to see you today, I was kind of planning to say like this doesn’t look like it has been working that well, maybe we should switch to something else. After speaking to you, and hearing it from you, I’m kind of backtracking a little bit and I’m beginning to think like maybe we should give this a chance to work a bit longer. Um, you certainly haven’t had like the best possible response that we could have expected. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We have seen patients who, even in the first two months, their PSA level drops by fifty percent, and the tumors begin to shrink. We certainly haven’t seen that. On the other hand, we haven’t seen like an obvious, uh, progression of the cancer either on the scans. So I would say, you know, you’re certainly not the best case scenario on this medication, but you’re by no means the worse, either, somewhere in the middle, and so that’s why I needed some input from you as far as what you think we should do. I’m willing to stick with this a little bit longer. We don’t want to wait too long so that, you know, if something bad happens like one of your bones fractures or pain gets excruciatingly worse, uh, and so, and on the other end of the spectrum as well, your anemia is still there, so your hemoglobin level was still below nine. It was about eight point nine, uh, on the most recent check, and even if we decided to continue on this study at the very least between now and your next visit- is that September fourth? Family Member: Fifth. Doctor: Fifth? We would need to, again, hold the drug. Because even at the lower dose of two-fifty, it’s still causing, you know, that significant anemia. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, I just want to get a sense from you whether you think you might, you know, want to stick with this for about two more months until the next set of scans? Whether you feel that you’ve had enough and you want to try something new? Or like where are you at with this? Patient: Well- Family Member: So, can I give you my perspective-? Doctor: Yeah. Please. Yes.

Family Member: Because kidneys wouldn’t do that. It wouldn’t push back and forth like that. Doctor: No and if it’s the lymph nodes that are pushing, there may be a little bit of pain from that. Family Member: From one side to the other but.. Doctor: Yeah. But it’s still, it doesn’t sound cancer related. It almost sounds muscle or… Family Member: I think his back’s out of whack. Doctor: Or back. Family Member: He does see a chiropractor. Doctor: Okay. Patient: On occasion I do. Plus I started swinging golf clubs again and mowed the lawn. Family Member: That explains it. Patient: So I got stuff going on here. Doctor: After next week it’s gonna be much more in pain then if you’re gonna make him work hard. (Laughs)

Patient: The enzalutamide. I, I don’t remember being on that. Doctor: Xtandi. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Yeah. We have to use the generic name. The, the drug company, they want the one that they want -- the fancy name. Um. So (Pause) Patient: Well, uh, the gentleman, M_, said he had one more chemo for me, but he didn’t have much faith it would do anything. So, maybe it was the same. Doctor: Well, it is – you never know until you try. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: And this is a – when we look through all the things about what could you do that’s different in here, uh, we have this clinical study – Patient: Oh. Doctor: - and the first thing that we had to check is you had to be ARV seven expressing. Patient: That was so Doctor: So you are ARV seven positive. Patient: Ah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, the computer flips a coin and says whether you’re getting it or not. But you still would be coming in two times a week to get an infusion. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That infusion could be real stuff, real vitamin C. Or it could be sugar. Patient: Okay. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay? Huh, so it really is asking a lot of you to give us extra time to sort out whether giving vitamin C makes a difference. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So the theory is vitamin C in high doses may have a, let you have less side effects from the chemotherapy. Huh, at high doses, it may make the chemotherapy work better. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Old data says that sometimes if you take too much vitamin C when you’re getting chemotherapy it could protect the cells, in this case the cancer cells, which we don’t want to protect, and maybe make the chemo work less well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But have less side effects. Okay? So that’s why we have the dummy pill. Okay? Patient: Okay.

Patient: No, no. I, I came here because Dr. T___ out at S__ say, say, oh, you know, certainly recommended it. I guess he’s part of this study too, so. Doctor: He is. He is. Patient: So uh he felt pretty strongly that coming here to participate but also to, to say here is- Doctor: Remind me again how you hooked up with him. Patient: Yeah. Through the urologist that I had that did the surgery. Doctor: Because you’re mostly east coast. You, you moved? Patient: Yeah. We lived in C___ for twenty one years. Doctor: That’s right. That’s right. Patient: We, we were out there. Doctor: That’s right. Patient: Everything was there, except summertime. Doctor: I remember. You moved to uh-

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It turns out that the genetic material of the cancer cell, which is called the DNA. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in order for that cancer cell to be able to replicate itself, to cause you know two cells from one and then four cells, eight cells, it needs to be able to replicate its DNA and then replicate itself after that. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And it turns out when you give high doses of testosterone in the setting where that cell has previously been in a low testosterone environment - Patient: Okay. Doctor: It causes the DNA molecules in the cell, the genetic material of the cancer cell, to break into smaller pieces. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the DNA molecule basically shatters into these small pieces and that damage is so catastrophic that the cell is unable to fix those DNA breaks and because the DNA molecule has been broken up into small little pieces, that cell can’t replicate itself and it dies. Patient: Oh! Doctor: So that’s the theoretical mechanism. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Yes, yes. But we found that to be one of the cholesterol medications I was taking at the time. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And plus that in addition to I was getting a little cramp in my side. And so we stopped. Doctor: Well with age, so-called metabolic syndrome increases in many people. And so what that means is you know your sugar levels become higher and um your metabolism changes in such a way as a result of that. And this may also cause other downstream effects on the down the line. For example, it might slightly increase the risk of having a cardio-vascular disease or a heart attack, for example, or cerebral-vascular disease like a stroke. If the blood glucose level is not controlled over time. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So all of the things that Metformin does is it changes your metabolism in such a way that the blood glucose level is lower and therefore it puts you at decreased risk of dying with those things that I mentioned. Patient: I’m sorry, it also mentioned that Metformin is a cancer fighter. Doctor: Right, there is some evidence which I would call modest. You know in other words it’s not absolutely conclusive, but it’s not you know terribly weak either um that , at prostate cancer specifically, and other cancers in general, there might be a direct anti tumor effect Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Now uhm I am somewhat convinced by the data. Uhm the perfect way to prove that, and this may never happen, is to actually design a trial. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Where you take people that already have a diagnosis of prostate cancer – Patient: Uh hum.

Patient: Yeah! You told me he talked to you. Doctor: I know. Patient: You say. Doctor: So, I said, I know you. That if we did that and everything else, you would just sort of give up. You’d be like, “I’m done. I can just barely -- my quality of life is here.” But I have to tell you, if you really needed it. One, I think your quality of life would actually be much better because you’d be so symptomatic from that problem, you couldn’t ride your bike. You couldn’t go around the block. You couldn’t do anything! You’d just be soiling yourself constantly! So, if that came to be the issue, you would want it done just to improve your quality of life. Patient: Okay. Listen. Doctor: But I also know that that’s not something you would do proactively because the thought of having a bag scares the heck out of you. I know that. I got it. And now I just threw in two possible bags that’s even more frightening. So, I need you to focus on what we have to do next. We gotta get some systemic stuff swirling through your bloodstream – Patient: Okay, but -- Doctor: To get control. We’re fixing it here, but the rest of you is not controlled. Doctor: Okay? Hi!!! Patient: So. So. Doctor: We’re having all sorts of discussion! Healthcare Professional 2: Really?

Healthcare Professional: Yeah Doctor: Okay. So then I- for now I'm going to stay with the same dose. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I think the next step before this tearing and everything, and we are getting up there in number of cycles you've gotten, Patient: Correct. Doctor: we may need to consider cutting back on the dose or-- Patient: Okay. Doctor: --taking a break for a longer time or- Family Member: He needs a break. Doctor: --whatever. Patient: 'Cause that break really was nice, it worked out well the way it--I mean-- Doctor: I think your last time you really looked, uh, tired out.

Patient: Thank you, Yeah thank you. Doctor: So it’s finally actually going in the right direction. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you will need to continue on the prednisone also which I forgot to ask you are you still on that? Patient: I’m still taking it yeah. Patient: Give a little bit of comfort. Doctor: Um hum. Well and you could do that, but I think there are other true medicines that you could try to kind of knock down the pain.

Patient: Okay, that’s fine… Doctor: ‘Cause I don’t think it’s related… Patient: Right. Doctor: …however all these other doctor’s appointments all gotta go right according to plan… Family Member: Yes. Doctor: …so that we don’t make you worse because there’s still no matter what some clearance of you know, any of the medicines are always somewhat cleared, some percentage by the kidneys so… Patient: Right I understand that. Doctor: …we don’t want to make that worse. Okay. Family Member: Mhmm. Patient: Right. Well we looked up the side effects of uh Doctor: Mhmm. The enzalutamide. Yeah. Patient: …uh the enzulamide, whatever. Um there wasn’t anything in there that indicated a kidney uh… Doctor: Right.

Patient: Okay. When do you get a bone scan, yearly? Doctor: Yeah. Depending on how you do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. So today all you had was a CAT scan or did you have both? Patient: Yes. Yes. No. Just a scan. Doctor: Oh. So you didn’t go to D___, then? Patient: Oh, no. I saw what you said, yeah. Family Member: He went here. Doctor: Oh. You went here? Patient: Yeah. I misunderstood. Yes. Doctor: Okay. I didn’t realize, okay. Patient: Well, last time I got the bone scan in D___.

Family Member: Alright. He said, oh, it’s, you know, it’s some weird- Doctor: Oh, my, oh, my, God. That is a scary thing to say and leave it hanging like that. Patient: I think he was trying to get rid of me. I don’t know. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. Yeah. That’s not something we would ignore or taken lightly, either. Patient: Okay. So then you’re going to give me an appointment for three months here? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. And um if anything changes on the scan, we’ll let you know. Patient: You’ll call me, and- Doctor: But you need your injection. Right? Today? Patient: Yes. Um hum. But in three months, I’ll get another CAT scan? Patient: Maybe not? Doctor: Yes.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So if someone has an intermediate or low Gleason score, the PSA level is less than fifty it’s rising at a slow pace… it’s better after six months. to start the hormone therapy. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Unless, the PSA or Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But to me if it’s a combination of both factors. Again, if you ever have a symptom from your cancer, then typically that is what I would strongly recommend. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So stopping with the clinical trial therapy and preceding with non-hormonal therapy. time to try something else. Patient: And that would be the … Doctor: That would be the example. Patient: Okay. Can you tell me my Gleason score? Doctor: Your Gleason score was a seven out of ten and that was based on your in two thousand and seven.

Family Member: So in other words this third option, the chemo and the hormones—so when the chemo ends he’ll be getting radiation while he continues to get the hormone therapy. Is that – it starts now? Okay. Doctor: About every three months. Family Member: I’m sorry if you said this, but how long does the radiation go? Doctor: The radiation takes two months, coming to the hospital five days a week. I forget where you live. Patient: C___

Patient: I might toot, but then after that no problems. Doctor: Very good. So it sounds like everything else is fine. Any new medical problems with your heart, lungs, bowels are functioning fine? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay fine. Patient: No. Doctor: So we just got to resolve this social issue. Patient: Yes. Doctor: That’s the biggest thing. Patient: Is it time for me to get up you know. Doctor: Yes, I hear ya. Patient: You know from the biopsy, not by biopsy from my colonoscopy I’ve been asking you about when we wait some more. Doctor: Yeah right yes.

Family Member: I thought he was talking about others who – Patient: No! I don’t have a melanoma. Family Member: No. Patient: He said, he said you should consider taking it. Doctor: I am interested in that. It’s kind of, um, I don’t know if it’s because Nicotinamide somehow absorbs sunlight or how it would work? Patient: Well. I don’t know. Look at the alien show. Maybe you can figure it out. Doctor: Well. They’re all green, so they have a different problem. So.

Patient: So I should be good for three weeks anyway? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um hum. We can fill one of those papers out. Yeah. Patient: Okay. What else did I have? Doctor: If you need to go upstairs, you can. Patient: You can go up and take care of it. DOC Everything else will improve if you start to eat. I think he got that medicine that he gave me, your husband gave me… Doctor: Yep. Patient: I think it got some refills and I think I got about two more refills. Doctor: Good. Patient: But I’ve been taking it though. Doctor: Perfect. Patient: Yep I’ve been taking it. Yep I have been taking it. Patient: Are you gonna give me the sixty OxyContin? Doctor: Yeah I gave you. One is sixty and then the Percocet is a… Patient: One hundred twenty? Doctor: One hundred twenty. Patient: Okay, last time you gave me OxyContin, you gave me one hundred twenty. Doctor: I know because that was the short acting. That’s what I’m telling you. The short acting OxyContin you had one hundred twenty. This is the long acting.

Patient: Okay, so. Doctor: Okay. Patient: All right. Doctor: Well, good. It was nice to see you. Doctor: Well I’ll have her call you too. But that way, you know that at your convenience if you're at work, and she calls you that you can call her back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Oh, good. Okay, cool. Sit tight here and I have a feeling, wait, wait. Go ahead. See that I knew this young lady would be waiting on me.

Patient: Oh, I hope my teeth can stand it. (sighs) Doctor: Okay. So we saw you the beginning of April. How you feeling? Patient: Okay. Uh, I guess about five o’clock in the afternoon, uh I run out of gas. Doctor: Uh, runs out of gas. Uh, so, what does that mean? You have to take a nap or you just -- ? Patient: I have to, I have to sit. I did mow the grass, but, um, it gets. Patient: Nope. I don’t do much at all. Doctor: And what are you missin’ out on? Doctor: So you’re not – (housework) Patient: Yeah. Chores. (Pause) Doctor: But it gets done the next day or next – or you get it done eventually – or? Patient: Eventually. Laying kitchen floor right now. Doctor: Have you had any falls? Patient: No.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But my expectation is just to be very honest is that yes, there will be some degree of PSA reduction. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And it may delay the need for hormone therapy for another six months from now with another twelve months from now. Patient: Uh hum. And that we have also done - there have been trials to support that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you know the clinical trials and also the clinical experience do suggest that when you combine standard hormone therapy with chemotherapy or standard hormone therapy with newer type of hormone therapy called (novel) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. But but again, I don’t want you to go into that thinking that it’s going to increase the chance of a cure. The cure rate is still you know pretty close to zero percent and that it increases the length of time that that systemic therapy works. Patient: Okay. And see, that that that’s my concern at this point. Um you know um you think in terms of the reason I keep pushing hormonal so far back is because I know that’s a proven method - Doctor: Yeah. It is -

Patient: Right… Doctor: Right? Patient: …and after that you guys are supposed to take it over. Doctor: Okay, alright we’ll do that. Patient: I don’t ever see Dr. R____ no more over there. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Every time I go in… Doctor: You just go and get your injection? Patient: Yeah and I think it would be better off do everything here. Doctor: Okay. Well I’m just wondering then if we should hold off and uh because we may have to switch him to Firmagon if he’s not getting enough suppression. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, okay. Doctor: Okay so why don’t you hold off on the injection tomorrow.

Patient: Yeah. You have. Doctor: Because we did it before the testosterone, during the testosterone, during the enzalutamide, and we try to look at how those treatments affect it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I’ll, I’ll find out. Patient: Alright. Doctor: So- Family Member: I wanted, I want your input, uh but we couldn’t just give him that - because he is all at that level of three injections of testosterone, he’s a perfect candidate just for that immune thing just to see? (Beeping) Doctor: Well, the immune thing is normally I, I don’t. We’re not allowed to give anything unless it’s in a disease where it’s been approved- Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: because the cost is so very high, the hospital won’t let us do anything. So normally what we have to do is go through the insurance company, tell them what we wanted to do, they deny it, you write letters. So it’s not something that I can just do it tomorrow. Family Member: So you can’t ask-? Doctor: Now you, you know, who have, you’re a person of means, that maybe you could just pay for it, but I haven’t really, I don’t know what the avenue is to do that. (Laughs) Family Member: Well-

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh in the past you know we talked about the backup plan. Patient: Right. Doctor: What will we do - the day that I say hey, you know this isn’t working or you say I don’t want to do this anymore. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, We checked, you know, the one, the new therapy setting still where you live at. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Some of it is sometimes that blood test that’s fluctuating could be better. Usually it doesn’t. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So we would definitely have to repeat that again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because if you’re seven and remained positive, then you’re eligible for one study versus another study. Patient: Oh.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But, I I did want to speak to you about um a research study that we’re doing that I think would be a good fit for you and I wanted to give you some details about that. Patient: Mm-kay. Doctor: And then give you some time to uh look at some written information that I’ll give you to take home. And you can look at that with your sister and your great-niece and the three of you can decide together whether you think this might be good idea for you. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And um I just wanted to um write some notes down. And then after I write these notes, I’m going to give you some detailed information about the the clinical trials. So, if if you are not at J_____ H_____. If you were just seeing a medical oncologist without- private practice or community um then the next step for someone like you, where the cancer might be growing or progressing despite the Abiraterone- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But typically we want to have two options. Number one would be switching from that pill to a different pill. And the second pill is called Xtandi. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: That is also known as Enzalutamide. Got a long name. The short name is Xtandi, the long name is Enzalutamide. And this is a pill you take it every day and it’s also four pills at a time. Four pills all at once. The dose is one hundred sixty milligrams. So it’s a little bit different from the Abiraterone. And this one does not require Prednisone, no Prednisone for this one. So it’s one less thing to take. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: The second option for some patients, whose cancer is progressing more rapidly, especially in those that its causing symptoms, like bone pain for example.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we actually have another study which may or may not be open in time which is a pill plus another pill. The pill is Patient: I’m available all day tomorrow. Doctor: Okay. I will have to work with the group to see what they can do to get that. Patient: Or or I can, I can be s - I can be wherever I need to be at like seven o’clock on Wednesday morning. Doctor: Okay. Okay. Patient: Is it - That’s about what, a two hour deal? Doctor: Mm probably longer. I would just spend, I would just block off a half a day because they’re probably gonna put you in that happy place like when you get a colonoscopy happy place. Patient: I am awake during my colonoscopies. I go into twilight. Doctor: You’ll be in twilight, you’ll be in twilight. Patient: Just ‘cause I like to look at the – doctor uh. Doctor: Oh you’re like, you like to actually be awake.

Patient: I- because I been taking that medicine. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And then then I be feelin’- I be for the last Doctor: Okay. Patient: Sometime that would go away. Sometime it stay with me the whole day so. I I wadn’t worryin’ that I’m sayin’ I’m wonderin’ i-i-s it possible its cancer or medicine so. Doctor: In addition to the heartburn, are there any other new symptoms. Are you having any pain in the bones or elsewhere? Patient: Yesterday for some reason all in my back was pain from my shoulder blades, to my shoulders all through my back. And I took a uh Nap-nabarone. Doctor: N-naprosyn. Patient: Yeah I took and sleep Doctor: Okay. And did you take one today as well? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. So it didn’t come back today?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - is we want to know whether your immune system is reacting to it. So our study isn’t whether you get the medicine or not. You get the medicine, regardless. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Our study is, will you allow me to get extra tubes of blood so I can measure these things that are affecting the immune system, so we get knowledge? That’s it. So there is no sugar. Family Member: Right. Doctor: There is no, you know, what we call placebo, or there is nothing that is not what is the treatment coming to you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Hum? Patient: Cancer’s like, uh, cancer is like a mucous. Doctor: Cancer is like a mucous? Patient: Huh. Doctor: Nah Family Member: I was always taught it’s an overgrowth of whatever.

Patient: By whenever yeah, Doctor: Something like that, okay. Patient: two weeks ago today. Doctor: Yeah, okay. Let me give you the brief summary of what I think is happening because I know you like it itemized so we have a plan. One, your PSA’s going up but not unexpected. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because we talked about how Provenge just doesn’t touch that PSA. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But more concerning is just you have more lymph nodes or they’re not even technically lymph nodes they’re more… Patient: Nodules. Doctor: …nodules in the belly whereas before… Doctor: Yeah. It’s more of the schmutz that we talked about… Patient: Um hum.

Family Member: Hi. Nice to see you. Doctor: So, you know, you done good. Family Member: It got better. Doctor: How about that? Family Member: Good news. No new treatments. Doctor: Yeah. I think you get a break for six weeks until I torture you with that, I mean help you, again. Family Member: What’s that going to involve? Patient: What’s going to happen in six weeks? Doctor: Nothing. I just want to make sure your PSA isn’t like skyrocketing. (Door sound) Patient: Oh. Doctor: You know? Ten, ten is okay. Patient: Oh, ten isn’t climbing?

Family Member: They are cold. Doctor: Okay! What are we going to do? (chair movement) Family Member: Can you -- I’m lost here. Doctor: And then, if somewhere along the way, it improves, great. I’m talkin’ about the fistula and this whole – Patient: Right. You could the, you could do the pills.

Healthcare Professional: Okay. Doctor: Beautiful. Okay. Need any refills on anything? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. So hang on and watch out for the uh yeah uh the diet and we’ll see you back in six weeks. Piece of cake. Patient: Six weeks? Doctor: Sure. Is that legit? Are you going to behave for six weeks? Patient: Oh, I always behave. Patient: Life is so boring. Doctor: Did I give you the nutrition book last time? Patient: No. Doctor: Oh, good. Parting gift. Patient: Parting gift?

Family Member: I see. Doctor: Abiraterone is probably what I would prefer. Although for you, the downsides of it is potentially, you know, fluid retention. Huh, there is a lot of fatigue related to it. Huh, huh, we have to watch your blood tests a little bit. Huh, about seventy-five percent, three out of four people, their PSA is going to drop on it. Huh, the average person’s on it for about fifteen months, then the cancer figures it out, and we have to look at maybe moving to something else. We don’t change therapy based on PSA. We base it on how you’re feeling and whether your scans show more cancer than what we saw today. Okay? Patient: Now, what would you recommend right now? Doctor: Yeah. I, I like the abiraterone but we’ll have to check to sort of see what the cost is to you. The other one doesn’t need prednisone. It makes people a little bit more frail so I’m a little bit more worried about that one in you. Huh, you know, we don’t have right offhand a clinical trial that I can think about. Our first study with abiraterone, you have to have a mutation which you don’t have. So we would just be able to give you abiraterone. Our enzalutamide plus new drug first-line study is on hold right now. Huh, the two other studies that we have all require that you have had abiraterone or enzalutamide. Huh, so usually after one of these drugs if your cancer is getting worse more options from a clinical trial perspective open up. Huh, we just finished our study of radiation and a vaccine. We don’t know if that has any activity or working yet to see whether or not, huh, that would be a standard option. Huh, you aren’t eligible, so right now, it would be the abiraterone that we would head towards. So what I typically do is send an email to our pharmacy saying can you price this out, then speak to you about whether you can afford it or not afford it, and then, huh, they work on sort of the patient assistance program, if you need it. Huh, if you don’t need it or you get one of those things, then they can provide the drug. Huh, we might have you come in and meet with that pharmacist or one of the nurse practitioners that I work with, huh, to sort of just re-go over what you may feel with starting the new drug, or that if, again, we just can’t get it for you, we can try the other one, or we would think maybe even going to the radium, which is a liquid radiation drug, which is given here in the clinic. Usually that’s what we go to next. Patient: That’s what I had before but they, radia, huh- Doctor: Rad. Patient: She injected me with something. Family Member: No. No. Doctor: You’ll continue on your hormone shots every three months for the rest of your life. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so I’ll set that visit up for sure. Huh, and then, huh, hopefully within the next couple of weeks we’ll be able to figure out where you are and you can get started on the abiraterone. Patient: Okay. The pills that you told me to stop taking, should I go back on them?

Healthcare Professional: And if he feels like he’s having side effects or just doesn’t want to do it anymore or participate, just let me know. Doctor: Same thing. Doctor: Whether you’re on the study or not, you have a problem at one a.m. on a Saturday, you still page me. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Same. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But we appreciate… Healthcare Professional: But you can always call me too… (laughs) Doctor: Yeah. (Laughter)

Patient: I’m, I’m interested in. Doctor: Let me, uh- Patient: And plus it also, it, its information that could be useful to maybe help other people. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, if it looks like you can’t, if it looks like you would fit on the trial, we can talk about them more. If, if it looks like the bone thing is going to eliminate that-

There’s, there’s some nice places on this list too. Patient: Called the T___. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Oh that’s a nice.

Well, I, I think that’s also part of this is getting me and the radiation folks together ‘cuz I think we’re ordering redundant now. I mean, they ordered a test; I ordered a test. Family Member: Of how I see it going? And then he can correct me if I’m wrong. Doctor: We’ve got a thing to keep in mind is in your case we decided to try this study because of the genetic mutations that your tumor had. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it wasn’t that we tried this study because you had exhausted all other options. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the reason we’re saying that is because there are other things out there that your cancer has a good chance of responding well to. For example, uh, the alternative hormone therapy called Xtandi, that you have not received. You have received the one called, Zytiga. But there’s a similar one that was FDA approved about a year after the Zytiga was approved, called Xtandi. And it’s an oral hormone therapy pill. That medication does not work that well after people have received Zytiga first because it’s similarly related to that drug, but that’s an option. The second option is intravenous chemotherapy, which you have also not received. Um, which I know that you have been reluctant to think about it in the past, but that clearly is an option. So you have a minimum of two FDA-approved options that you have not tried yet. So knowing that, um, from my perspective, like I’m going to be a little less sort of heroic and like waiting to see if this is going to work or not. Because it’s not like you’ve run out of options, and this is the last thing we’re going to try anyway. You know? There are other options out there. Because we do have those options, yes, one of them is a chemo. Um, we also don’t want this cancer to advance too quickly that we miss the window and you get too sick and too frail, you know, to be able to tolerate those other therapies. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that, that is also in the back of my mind. And, because, because then I feel like we might have actually harmed you by missing the opportunity to give, you know, an FDA-approved therapy. Of course, that would be through K___ because that would be standard therapy. Um, so that’s what the other part of my thinking. Patient: Okay. And, and from my perspective, I didn’t believe that this was going to be easy from the, from the beginning. I remember when I came, I came to J___ H___ for a reason. I came here for a consultation because I wasn’t comfortable, uh, with the options that I believe K___ was offering. I came initially for that reason. It’s strange that it was my dentist, so we talk about a lot. It’s strange how you get into certain things, uh, by having relationships with people who have gone through it. My dentist had, uh, numerous family members, had dealt with cancer, and he had recommended, he said, you know what, D___, this is what you need to do. You need to go to one of the teaching hospitals either here in DC you can go to J___ H___, in B___, and from my perspective, there are enough individuals that have come to J___ H___, that are close friends of mine. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That said, they shared with me that, uh, if you have a choice, go to J___ H___. So when I came up, my thing was the consultation. We had the consultation. I left, and, uh, and I didn’t say anything. But there was a follow-up that was set for J___ H___. And we sat down, and we talked about this. So we have all these options here. We did the genetic testing. And I said, okay, this is an option just like anything else. If it does not work, it’s not like it’s the only option that we have. Doctor: Correct.

Patient: That’s what I do. Doctor: I know. Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: Gee, you and every other guy I have in my practice which is why I say this. Patient: Oh, Okay. Now, sometimes people just take it twice a day, kind of like before bed for sure so you sleep well Patient: Right. Doctor: and then when you’re kind of up and running whether it’s after breakfast and you’re like I’m gonna get as much stuff as I can done and I’m just gonna relax and wait for my next dose. Some of my guys have to take it three times a day and some of my guys are just like I’m okay, I can stand this stuff, it’s doable but at night I just can’t sleep. It’s just there all the time the achiness and pain. Patient: Right. Doctor: and they take it at night. However you do it just know it will constipate you. Patient: I know that, yes.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it just seems like when we give someone on hormone treatment, two hormone suppressions, it sort of falls off the table, and you, it just magnifies all those symptoms. I would say, I have a subset of men who respond really well for a long time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Often, you know, a couple of years. I have another group that respond really well, but it’s not very long lived, maybe a couple of months, six months. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then a third group that doesn’t respond at all. Uh, so that would be the easiest thing. That’s a, you know, that’s the prescription. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That, that’s choice one. Choice two would be to give you chemotherapy at this point. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I think, for me, what I would prefer is to try another hormone pill before we do chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: But there is a newer hormonal therapy that also we can consider for you. Now that is sort of an earlier phase trial, so it’s a phase one trial. Okay. But the advantage is that we’ve already been through a number of the dosing levels. So typically a phase one trial is where you’re getting something very new that’s worked amazingly well in the lab that now you’re testing in people. So the first few dose levels really are trying to see what kind of side effects and what dose level really has… Patient: Sure. Doctor: But you’ll have some long days and things like that, you would have the hotel and mileage covered you know same as this study for that matter. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. (clears throat) Doctor: So those things would be covered, but it is a matter of whether you’re willing to come back and forth.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So what they found is if you give a little bit of prednisone, which is also kind of a hormone, it balances that out. It makes them eat more. Patient: Oh. (Laughter) Doctor: And so, uh, the standard dose was twice a day. We found that if we just give it once a day, it’s enough to counterbalance the thing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so I think either one would be fine. You know? I think choosing either one would be fine. Doctor: They will go and look at your insurance. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Figure out what X is going to cost. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: What’s the best pharmacy to get it from?

Family Member 1: Yes, super hormones uh for what duration? Doctor: We, uh I give them for three months for four doses of chemo three weeks apart. Doctor: Um yes, so, so, you’re talking about like PSMA radionuclide therapy and um right now there are a couple of clinical trials in the United States for guys who have failed hormone therapy. There are also – um you can do that – I’ve sent probably; uh I’ve sent twelve guys over to Germany to get that therapy in the last eighteen months uh you know specifically to try and like avoid like hormone therapy or something. What I can tell you is in this setting that therapy is not curing anybody. So if you’d asked me eighteen months ago, I would have said sure, let’s send you over there. What I’ve learned in the last eighteen months is that nobody I’ve sent over has been cured by that therapy, and uh I don’t consider it worthwhile right now. Doctor: Yeah, uh so the biggest side effect, quite frankly, so let’s talk about hormones first. Uh because the super hormones don’t add anything. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Oh. Doctor: Now one of the things that I also wanted to discuss with you was some um of the clinical trials that we’re doing. In other words, research studies – Patient: Uh huh. Now testosterone feeds the cancer, correct? Doctor: Correct. I knew you’d say that. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So this is quite a paradoxical approach. Patient: Okay, good. Doctor: And it turns out that you’re absolutely right. We’ve known for a long time for about seventy years that testosterone can feed into your prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: However, we have recently discovered in the last three or four years that they can take a patient who has had low testosterone levels for a very long time they call that hormone-resistant prostate cancer or castration-resistant prostate cancer is another term Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. So, are we, or why, are we trying these other things because - and it could be both answers - because you want to know? Or because, they’re the most effective options for me? Doctor: So. (Pause) Patient: I don’t want to compromise your ethical considerations. Doctor: So, in the realm of standard treatment, the two treatments that we have that are new hormonal treatments, we call them “Second Line Treatments.” So, the, the Lupron/Eligard is the first one. We would add a second one. Both of those have been tested in big clinical trials, and both of those showed an improvement in survival for a large group of men. It wasn’t a huge improvement. Um. But it reduced your risk of dying of prostate cancer by about thirty percent. The survival improvement was on the order of months, but that is really, uh, for the whole group. It’s hard to call the individuals outta that. Um, so that’s kind of the baseline that we know. Um. And, those drugs, you know, they have side effects that we need to manage, but that’s kind of would be the next treatment that’s standard treatment. It’s approved by the FDA because of the survival improvement. The new finding about this new drug, they’re called “PARP” inhibitors. A group did a study in England where they had fifty guys who had some DNA mutation, mostly BRCA2. They treated the fifty guys; sixteen had mutations. And, they found that none of the people without the mutations responded. Fourteen of the sixteen - so, you know, ninety percent who had a mutation responded to these drugs very well. Suggesting, they’re probably going to work really well in patients like that. Um. Patient: Am I one of those people? Doctor: Yeah, you’re one of those people. Now, that drug hasn’t been through the big paces of FDA trial approval. That’s where it is right now. So, the trials we’re looking at are looking at giving that drug alone or in combination with these standard hormones. So, the trial that I would consider for you have multiple arms. We could talk about that in detail, but, it’s there’s two different trials they could either combine the drugs or give you one drug. Um. But, the, but the, where the field is moving is there’s going to be fifty trials of this to try to nail this down. Family Member: Now, you said immuno--- Doctor: So, the other thing that’s a little further back in time Patient: But, did you say multiple “harms?” Doctor: Hormones. Patient: Hormones. Okay. Doctor: So, one of the trials is you get --

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it determines how toxic things were. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So with drugs what will often happen is a patient on a phase one where you came at an early stage you’d get a very low dose, probably too low to have toxicity but too low to be effective. And when you get to the high dose, it might be plenty to be effective but toxic, so you’d always sort of be Goldilocks at the end. Patient: Yeah. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: and you know, depending on what your scans show, I actually would favor Provenge, which is the vaccine therapy, because it’s almost like a flu shot. We don’t really know what happens to the PSA but we do know that if you get it in people who get it Patient: Is that a shot or is that through? Doctor: So, here’s where it gets a little complicated. You know, the flu shot is also like a vaccine. That, you know, you just get here. But, in cancer it’s a little bit more complicated. So, what we would do is actually send you to the Red Cross right across the street. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: They hook you up to a machine and then they take out your cells so they’re not using my cells or anybody else’s cells. They’re taking out your cells, your immune cells so that when they take it they ship it to Atlanta so if you’ve never been to Atlanta, your cells will be. They wake it up and then they ship it back to me, the like better version of you and then I reinfuse it back to you so that your cells know to find the cancer. That’s the thought of how that medicine works. So, we do that, let’s say the Red Cross on a Monday, I get your stuff back like on a Thursday and then I reinfuse it to you on a Thursday. We do that 3 times and then the treatment is done. It’s self-limited. Okay. Patient: So, that’s your immune system. Doctor: That’s the immune system. Patient: So, what happens in between, does that weaken your immune system or? Doctor: No, it actually if anything strengthens. Patient: I mean while it’s out. Doctor: Oh, no. We don’t take everything out. We just take a few things out. Patient: Oh, okay.

Family Member: So it’s a monthly, a monthly thing? Doctor: So the treatment you actually take every single day, so, the pills, so what you what you do usually is that you come in, we make sure that you're taking you after usually fill out a drug diary so that we see how many like if you're missing days, you take the pills, and then we would give you refills of the pills. Family Member: Okay, so will there be a blood test when he comes back also? Doctor: Yeah. Not every single time. Family Member: oh OKAY. And how long is this trial for? Doctor: This one, I think it's for two years so that you can, you can stay on it. You can stay on it for two years. Usually, if people are getting benefit, and they're still on it, then usually we can work with the company to continue it. Even though technically the study ends. But that's not always the case. Technically. I mean, usually, that's not always the case. Family Member: But the study itself is for two years. Doctor: Yes, yes. Yes, yes. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: All right. So let me, um yeah, so this is the so this is the part that's part of the research that's going to be free of charge. So right now what we'll do is the blood for this is the specific gene that we're looking for. And then if you join the study, and you have the right genotype, we'll get all of these and then these other things are not part of their like part of standard treatment. So those don't get paid for by the study they get paid for by your insurance company as normal. Patient: By insurance. Doctor: So if you are okay with this, I will get your signature there and then. You have to put the time. Time is 450

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um many patients don’t like that term. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um so that’s just hormone resistant. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In that context only, if you give back super-high doses of testosterone to the patient, and the way that we do that is we give an intra-muscular injection. It’s an injection of testosterone into the muscle that is either thigh muscle or the butt muscle. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In about thirty to forty percent of patients it causes remissions. In other words it causes cancer either to shrink um partially or completely in addition to the PSA level to drop either partially or completely. Patient: I don’t understand how. Could you give me the basic outline as to how that is happening? Let’s say you have the person who is overweight; you give him more food. That doesn’t – Doctor: Yeah, as I said, as you pointed out, it seems like a paradox and it seems counterintuitive. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: And the reason is it has to do with the fact that um when the prostate cancer cell, the cancer cell has been in an environment where the testosterone has been deprived for so long, and then all of a sudden you give that cell back a super-high dose of testosterone, it shocks the system and it causes that cell to die. And the exact reason for that we’ve begun to tease it out and understand it better. Patient: Uh hum.

Patient: That’s the one. R____ Doctor: You’ll take that for thirty days, and that will be sent there electronically, so you would be able to pick it up later today. Patient: Okay. Eh, any particular time of day? I’m sure it will come with, just as long as it is around the same time every day. Healthcare Professional: It just says “take it approximately, about the same time each day.” And you can take it with or without food. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that will just cause, uh, a little bit of soft stool. Family Member: And it doesn’t counter testosterone production, just with the cancer using it. Doctor: Correct. Uh, the medicine in two weeks will get rid of production. Healthcare Professional: It’s a little due in two weeks, when you come in for your injection. You’ll have another chemo class, uh, um, uh, we’ll have you do the chemo which is normally mornings, um, I think. I think it is eight o’clock or eight fifteen that they start. Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: So, you could do the chemo class and then get your injection afterwards. Patient: Okay, that’ll work.

Family Member: it’s radium for sure? Doctor: Well, it’s radium as an option. You know, you guys might look at that and go um, I don’t know how I feel about it and after you talk to the radiation doctor who administers it, you know, some people might say oh, gosh, I just worried about it and I’d rather take chemo and that’s okay too. I’m just trying to make it so easy. I mean any and all of this is interchangeable. If you had just bone only, you could get chemo Patient: Okay. Doctor: but if you have not just bone you can’t get radium. So, radium is only good for one thing. You got bone you can get radium. Patient: Radium. Doctor: It can’t go anywhere else. So, if it’s anywhere else other than bone, no go on the radium. Taxotere, you know, chemo could be anywhere anytime, less picky. Patient: What happened to the radiation that I took for the forty some days? Whatever did that do any good or it did nothing or what? Doctor: Well, I think it’s controlling your local, you know. Patient: You think it made a difference? Okay. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Oh, I think so. Yeah, those aren’t the problem cells. Those guys are dumb and dead. It’s the smarter ones that are like party. They may have not been even in the field of radiation. They may have already been floating around. So, just to also make sure we talk about the genetics stuff that you did because the biopsy didn’t really yield anything… Patient: Right, okay, that’s one of the things. Doctor: Yeah, right, it kind of all went south after that but we did check your blood. If you remember we sent a couple of tubes to a company called Guardian Health Patient: Yes.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: For a while actually that was explored as a treatment against prostate cancer – Family Member: Oh. Doctor: - to give mega doses and I mean grams and grams of calcium. Patient: Didn’t work. Doctor: No it was worse. Laughs]] Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Not only did it not work, but pause]] Mm, hmm? Patient: So, then we’ll go up front and get the appointment. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When we leave. Doctor: So about well six weeks would be about June eighteen, so sometime that week I need a PSA.

Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: It’s amazing. I was very impressed. Patient: Well she reminded me of the bakery and I don’t remember the bakery. Family Member: Oh yeah we went to xxx]. Doctor: They’re known for their that specific bakery. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: You know it’s funny but at the check-in at the airline this guy wrote down the name of the bakery because I had no idea that it’s known for its desserts and bakery so I had to go there. chuckles]] Family Member: Oh yeah. Patient: So anyway back to the problem. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Your husband did what he does. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: And so this is gonna show us if if it worked?

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Not, not that there was anything different before or after. So, uh, the two drugs, about sixty plus percent of men respond overall. So that’s what I said. About two-thirds of the guys respond, and then one-third seems to have a long response, and one-third has a shorter response, and one-third don’t. Uh, in terms of how to pick which one of those two. Uh, for a while, I, I was picking Zytiga instead of Xtandi. Zytiga, the one complication with Zytiga, is you have to take a small dose of prednisone with it, uh, to kind of counterbalance how Zytiga works. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the one reason we would do that is because we had some trials, uh, that were after Zytiga. But the other reason was a tendency of less fatigue with the Zytiga than the Xtandi, in my experience. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Both drugs can cause fatigue. But it seems to be more common and often a little bit worse with Xtandi. So, uh, in my choosing those two, I have been choosing Zytiga, just for that reason. Uh, but the Xtandi is a little bit easier, because you just have to take Xtandi. You don’t have to take another drug. Patient: Right. Family Member: Why are you taking prednisone with it? Patient: So Doctor: So the Zytiga, so the way Xtandi works is, if you think that we talked before about the, the testosterone has to get into the cell and do stuff. It has to bind in something in the cell called receptors. So the best way to think about it is a ball and glove. Xtandi kind of, if, if the ball is testosterone, Xtandi looks like an orange. And so it gets in the glove, and it blocks the ball. It can’t get in there. Uh, Zytiga works in a different way. It blocks the enzymes that the body uses to make testosterone. So there’s all these different precursors. So start with cholesterol, and it goes through about ten steps, and ends at testosterone. When you block it, there’s some hormones that build up that can affect the kidney. Patient: Hum. Doctor: And those hormones can affect how you handle water and potassium.

Patient: So I all need to do now is go back to the lab and do… Doctor: No, no you’re probably gonna stay here and S__ will take you over because those are special tubes that she has to send out and all that. No it’s not back yet then. I’ll take a look and let you know but Patient: Okay. Doctor: If it’s back. Family Member: Next Friday we’ll be back to plan out the next step and…

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, but hormone therapy, uh as far as I’m concerned, it’s the worst part of the whole thing, right. It’s gonna put you into menopause, it stills your sex drive, it gives you hot flashes, and it slows your metabolism by you know twenty-five percent, so you have to decrease your calorie intake. And you have to exercise like a fiend, or you’re going to get fat, and you don’t want that. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um but the other thing is it just makes you more tired, you know. We’re making you into an eight-year-old guy – Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: -temporarily. Family Member: For two years. Doctor: Yeah. Different people. I’m overstating it a little bit, but people are more tired. And uh, but people are more tired. And, and but if you exercise, it’s not as bad. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you don’t have the side effects of an increased heart attack risk. You don’t have, your bones don’t get soft, your muscles don’t go weak; you know exercise is the key here. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Um, but um some guys have bad hot flashes. And some guys get depressed because their metabolism down. Um, but make no mistake, people keep working; they keep enjoying life; they’re just more tired. Family Member: Uh hum.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: So it’s very common to see cancer cells along the nerves. Family Member: And the nerves came out with the vesicles? Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Okay. And then the extra nodule that doesn’t say what that was. It just says it had extended out of one, the one positive node. Right? Doctor: So that’s not a ray of sunshine. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So node looks like that, actually they’re smaller. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And they can get cancer in them and then cancer can grow out of that a little bit. That’s extra nodule extension. Family Member: Um hum and you don’t know what that’s touching other nodes or other areas of the body?

Patient: Now with hormonal therapy, um it is not a cure. It’s just a uh–. Doctor: That’s correct… It’s - Patient: Okay, so it’s not a cure. It is actually killing cancer that’s already there as well. So it is actively killing cancer and starving it of testosterone. You are correct in the sense that um we don’t think that this hormone therapy can eradicate all the cancer leading to a cure so that if you stopped the therapy the cancer would not come back. Family Member 1: So you are going to put him on the docetaxel pill? Doctor: Right or you might get on just the regular IV. So the trial is not that you get both, but you're one or the other. I have something to run by you Doctor: Um hmm. Patient: with me going out of town and taking this. Would I be alright to travel? Doctor: Yeah. So, the good news is that we figured out that you will leave with a piece of paper after the radiation doctor gives you the injection because you will set off the TSA sensors. Patient: Okay Doctor: You will actually set off most sensors even though if you spilled it, which you don’t want to spill fifteen thousand on the floor but oops if you’re butterfingers and it goes ping all you have to do to stop the radiation spread is actually put a piece of paper over it and the way the rays, they don’t, it’s not like, it’s not what we call a beta emitter where it just goes crazy and everybody has to run, duck, and cover and take a little tick, tick, tick, you don’t have to do that. It covers it and it’s gone. But, the TSA sensors are so sensitive that it’s even below the threshold of what the radium is. So, they do give you a card kind of like when you get a bone scan, Patient: um humm. Doctor: you know, they’re like oh, I just had a bone scan, they’ll be a similar card, but just make sure you travel with that because you’ll set it off. You know, within like a week after you get it, it should be fine Patient: Okay Doctor: but that’s important to know. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Um Doctor: Not ah truly applicable to you at this point. That’s great for if you were just newly diagnosed with your prostate cancer or if you have some specific area on your spine. You obviously just got the radiation to there but if you know you’re a baby, for example, and you had a really tiny spinal cord, and you have this cancer next to it, a proton would be the perfect treatment. For adults, it’s a little harder to know what is better than the standard. So you know you hope maybe if you got protons you wouldn’t have had so many side effects. That’s possible. But it’s not as mainstream I think as we’d like to see it. At some point now when they’re really up and running and more patients will get experience, we’ll probably get a better sense of that. But for now I think you’ve got the best treatment which was those three areas in the spine and then your pelvis. Family Member: But is this proton more precise than-? Doctor: It’s supposed to be but I think the question is you know for the extra twenty or thirty thousand dollars that it costs- Family Member: Um Hmm. Doctor: -is that truly better than what the regulation radiation is going to afford because it’s not the old time radiation. The radiation you got is still image guided. It’s still blocked off. So those studies are ongoing. And that’s why not every center and not every state has protons. Because the cost is just astronomical- Family Member: Really. Doctor: -and not every insurance company is really paying for it. And you don’t know if it’s better. So this issue comes around a lot because of prostate. So protons wanted to replace, you know, oh, and I going to save the bladder or anything else. And that data doesn’t show it to be better necessarily. So it’s a big fight between the radiation guys. They’re trying to figure that out themselves. Um, but I don’t know. I think it’s good technology. So I think if needed, if it was a really tough spot or really small area I think it’s reasonable. But you had many spots that the radiation had to go after so I’m not sure that much of an advantage would have been gained. Patient: Well this radiation I went through this time-

Doctor: So, do I advise that you go to the airport or to the Canadian border right after? No. Patient: No, that would not. Doctor: that’s not a good idea, no, no. But, you know, within a matter of like a few days it’s out. Now, its reasonably compared to all the other radiopharmaceuticals, easier to clean up. So, for example, if, and just for the record it’s like a fifteen thousand dollar vial. If you are oops and it lands on the floor, you don’t have to evacuate the building. Actually, what you do is you just put a piece of paper on there and then it’s protected. So, the half-life is really short but because it’s swirling in you as a human and then it stays in your bone which is why it’s only in the bone because it only goes to bone, um you will glow a smidge. So, we don’t want you to have like a newborn held up to you because you still will emit some sort of radiation.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. But some protocols do. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So those are just nuance of that type of escalation. Uh. You --- it would be a window. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then, we’re looking to see what they’re likelihood of benefiting men with prostate cancer are.

Okay? So you can get a pneumonia that’s from your immune system. You can get hepatitis because it’s attacking your liver. You could get colitis ‘cuz it’s attacking your colon. Uh, it usually picks one organ, not not all of ‘em, but, you know, you can get into trouble because your immune system – while it’s tryin’ to fight your cancer, it’s tryin’ to fight you. Uh. And then we have- usually the PSA goes up and then it goes down to zero after you get your prostate taken out. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: And then it'll go back up. That is what we call biochemical recurrence. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And that's when you have a rising PSA but negative imaging. Patient: Mm.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We have shown that to be true in the laboratory both in cancer cells which are being grown in a plastic dish in the lab. Patient: Right. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the first is, which is the most promising, is that the cancer goes into remission. That’s about one-third of patients. Patient: Uh huh.
